summary: When a young woman is killed by a shark while skinny-dipping near the New England tourist town of Amity Island, police chief Martin Brody (Roy Scheider) wants to close the beaches, but mayor Larry Vaughn (Murray Hamilton) overrules him, fearing that the loss of tourist revenue will cripple the town. Ichthyologist Matt Hooper (Richard Dreyfuss) and grizzled ship captain Quint (Robert Shaw) offer to help Brody capture the killer beast, and the trio engage in an epic battle of man vs. nature.

This is what great cinema is supposed to be.  I can say without any doubt that this is one of the greatest movies ever made.  The effects are stunning, the acting is phenomenal, the story is enticing, and the execution is great.

The movie starts with two teens trying to enjoy a late-night swim and the girl falls victim to the shark in one of the most iconic deaths of all cinema.  We cut to morning and one of my favorite film characters, Chief Brody, is introduced.  He ends up investigating the strange death and deduces it was a shark.  But Mayor Larry Vaughn does not approve because he wants to make money off of the tourists.

This situation spirals into Brody, an ichthyologist named Hooper, and a shark hunter named Quint going out into the sea on the Orca after the giant beast.  The scenes with them bonding as a group are great and hilarious, and the recounting of the USS Indianapolis' sinking by Quint probably displays the best acting and writing of the whole film.

All in all, this is an incredible movie.  The deaths are great, as is the acting and story.  One of my favorite movie villain deaths of all time comes in the form of Chief Brody shooting the oxygen tank in the shark's mouth and blowing him up.  I also have massive respect for everyone involved behind the scenes because this movie was a tough one to make, but I'm sure glad they came through.  Also, John Williams never ceases to make iconic scores.

The story of "Jaws" follows the story of the town Amity and its police chief Martin Brody, ship captain Quint and marine biologist Hooper dealing with a summer killing spree of great white shark attacks. 

Without diving into detail, I would say that this movie is good. Definitely the first of its kind and beautifully done by Steven Spielberg. 

 Does the movie hold up in 2022? Yes, there are many aspects of the film that I say can pass today's cinematic standards. The music is a big part that I want to speak on, the legendary soundtrack by John Carpenter certainly holds up today, the suspense it adds to each attack makes it even more terrifying . The Story plot is the one of the main parts that make this film a classic, the idea of a 20 foot long great white terrorizing and going on a killing spree is the first of its kind. The acting is definitely also a highlight of this film, the death scenes were so realistic, the two most realistic points were the opening scene with one of most terrifying and realistic frantic screams ever and the ending with Quints gruesome bloody death. 


Aspects of the film that I think would not pass today's standards . The end of the film, the ending seems rushed and not clearly thought out, like how the shark flops its head up on the deck of the boat and eats Quint when Hooper was just hiding in the water? Actually there were multiple points in the film that Hooper could have been killed another time was when he and Brody went out on Hooper's boat where they found the mangled ship, in this scene Hooper came face to face with the  shark. Regarding the shark prop, after the shark devours Quint and goes for Broady, the shark crashes through the glass window of the sinking boat,then you get a close up of the rubbery fiberglass prop, which sets off the terrifying scene. The shark prop would definitely not stand up to today's CGI effects. 


In the question of does "Jaws" hold up to 2022, I believe it could, the acting and story and the directing all together create a timeless classic some consider one of Steven Spielberg's greatest. This question is very argumentative on both sides.


I would recommend this to anyone in search of a good thriller/horror film, I would not suggest this film to someone who does not enjoy gory death scenes and someone looking for a super effects filled movie. 


Out of five stars I would rate this film a four out of five.

It's a beautiful summer night on the great vacation island of Amity Island. You decide you want to take a night swim then while you are 100 yards out, BOOM shark attack, you're gone. For this being a movie made in the 70's I feel like it holds up extremely well and was very entertaining 50 years later. A killer shark swims into town and is gifted with a summer feast with all of the swimmers, and boaters. After the first attack the chief fights with the mayor to shut down the beaches. The mayor declines due to it being so close to the 4th of July, and what is a vacation destination for if not to be open on the 4th of July. More attacks happen and the chief calls in a shark specialist, Hooper, to help. A shark hunter, Captain Quint, also comes to town with a hefty price to kill the shark. After more attacks the mayor agrees to pay the fee to kill the shark. The three set sail to kill the shark once and for all. After days of hunting, and battling, and opening up to each other, the final battle ensues and while Jaws did get one last dinner by eating Captain Quint, Chief Brody gets the job done and blows the shark up at the last possible second as the ship is sinking. 
   Did this movie hold up in 2022? I think it did. I think while the special effects, camera work, and even some of the acting have been vastly improved through the years it is still a good movie and very watchable and enjoyable in 2022. I think the plot of the movie holds up extremely well, there have been many shark movies since Jaws and they are all either trying to copy Jaws or just don't live up to the plot of Jaws. Some of the parts that don't "hold up" are the special effects, and camera quality. I put hold up in quotes because that is unfair to say hold up when technology has improved over the 50 years since this movie was made, so comparing it to movies in 2022 it will lose that battle but for its time some of the effects were very special and rare. The shark doesn't look good compared to today as I'm sure it was made out of paper mache or something like that while today you can CGI anything you want so it is unfair to compare. So I would say they are in between holding up or not, they have been very outmatched but it doesn't really take away from the viewing experience for me. The not so great effects of the shark almost make it better for me, a bit more cheesy and funny. Seeing the head of the shark pop up as it eats the guy on the kayak, and then when it is almost all the way on the boat eating Captain Quint it just adds a funny part to the movie even if it isn't supposed to do that it adds to the experience for me. The thing I disliked the most was some scenes that had seemingly random cuts to black screens then cut back to basically the same scene. One example was when everyone was at the docks looking at the shark they had caught and everyone thought it was over.  The chief was talking to Hooper and the Mayor and then it cut and the black screen appeared and then it just basically changed camera angles. It didn't need that cut to the black screen. It switched to him and Hooper still talking but the family of one of the children who died coming from the funeral and the mother slaps him blaming him for her child's death. Normally I feel like those cuts are used if you are changing time or changing to a whole new event, not just switching  from one camera angle to another. This happened a few other times and really stuck out to me. 
   If they did a shot for shot, line for line remake just with improved cameras, and special effects I think it would come out and be the number one movie for a long time. Most shark attack movies try to copy plot or story lines from Jaws, and that is because it holds up and is still so popular to this day. I would urge everyone to watch this film because I had never seen it, but I knew how everyone said it was good but I would think ‚ÄòIt's from the 70s will I actually enjoy it?' The answer was yes I did enjoy it, and if you are like me and like action movies with lots of killing then you will enjoy this movie too. I rate it 4 out of 5 stars.

Jaws is an incredibly interesting movie for its time. Its basic premise is about a small town dealing with a deadly shark and how a trio of heroes stepped up to defeat it. Honestly, I thought the movie was pretty good, and I can see why it's pretty popular even after all these years.

The movie absolutely holds up in 2022, despite having been made almost 50 years ago. One of my favorite scenes was when Captain Quint got killed by Bruce (the shark) and blood splattered everywhere. This scene, despite showing the rubber shark, looks so cool even today. This is all without me mentioning that Captain Quint is my favorite character, so his death is still pretty sad. I also really enjoyed the different ways the characters tried to fight the shark, such as Captain Quint harpooning it with the yellow barrels to chase after it and eventually Hooper scuba diving to try and fight it himself. Despite all this, some flaws still appear, as in all movies. An obvious one being how in some scenes, Bruce the Shark looks unrealistic. Everyone has said this a thousand and one times, but it's just true. Another part is how the town dealt with the shark attacks. Nowadays, people can just call an organization and easily let them deal with it, but it's also understandable since Amity Island seems pretty lonely.

Overall, I can definitely say you will like this movie if you're into suspense and blood. While it isn't bloody, there are scenes where blood is heavily shown. I really enjoyed the movie and can see why everyone thinks it's amazing.

A classic film loved by many, Jaws follows the hunt for a bloodthirsty shark and his explosive demise. As Amity is on the menu, a massive great white must be stopped by a rag-tag group consisting of a police chief, a marine biologist, and an old boat captain. As famous as this story of a small town vs. a sea monster is, it has lost the respect it once deserved. Between the poor cinematography, and poor animatronics, Jaws is a tale that should follow in the footsteps of Bruce.
Jaws is far from the worst movie of its time, and that's shown in how well much of the dialog holds up. The characters are often funny such as Brody trying to be a seaman. He's awful at tying knots, he doesn't know anything about boats, and he constantly complains, but it's amusing to see the shift in tone as for once Brody is acting immature and isn't the center of attention. We can also see excellent misdirection in the 4th of July scene. Not only is the fin hidden just enough it tricks the viewer into thinking they noticed a small detail, it's just two kids and takes the viewer off edge before the surprise attack in the pond. This first glance of the shark makes the animatronic look very impressive, but unfortunately it is the only time the infamous shark looks remotely convincing. 
From this point onwards, Bruce is never fearsome. While he has a few surprising jumpscares, I've seen paper mache look more convincing. Then as Quint is locked in his jaws, we get a wonderful long view of the shark animatronic. No longer is this a fearsome sea beast as the villain appears more as a latex children's toy, and moves in such a basic way it's predictable, it's not frightening, and it's boring. While I understand the difficulty in working with electronics in the water, let alone on that scale, the shark presented closes the movie looking unrealistic and as unnerving as a kitten compared to earlier on in the movie.
Overall, Jaws is not a poor movie, but it shows its age. You can clearly see this movie was made in the 70s with a 70s standard, and 70s technology. You will like Jaws if you can ignore the effects of a movie and get involved in the story. Jaws will make you wonder where the unseen beast is and had me on the edge of my seat wanting more than the glimpse of a fin, and supported by such an amazing soundtrack that is just another incredibly well known work of art by John Williams. However, if like me, you value the visual appeal of the movie and the realistic characters and setting drawing you in, much of this movie's appeal will be dragged away like a skinny dipping teen.

Great movie!  One of the all-time classics.  It weaves together the conventions of disaster movies which were big at the time; horror-thrillers like Alfred Hitchcock's The Birds; and adventure stories like Moby Dick.  Spielberg's ace in the hole has always been expertly mounting action set-pieces.  He is the master and he does not disappoint here.  (The original director was fired at the direction of author Peter Benchley who didn't like that he pitched to him a scene about a "whale").  Spielberg grounds the stories with characters we love and understand; this is not a trashy potboiler ala Peyton Place like the book was; the movie's u exploitive realism in the land scenes in Amity expertly sets off the over-the-top action scenes.  The acting from Dreyfus, Scheider and Shaw is also superb; all working at the top of their form; the palpable tension between Shaw and Dreyfus (which was quite real!) sets off sparks: and also helps to ground and realize the shark-kill scenes.  And John Williams visceral driving score is a masterwork!

The realism level is low here; great white sharks don't actually stalk and kill people; they eat minnows; this was actually inspired by the true story of a rogue TIGER shark which are much more dangerous.  And the number of deaths committed by all sharks pales in comparison in any given year to the amount of people killed by dogs, crocodiles or hippos for example.  (Or being bitten by disease-ridden mosquitos or being hit by a car; etc.) Man's primal and overweening fear of the shark is a somewhat irrational one mostly built on tall tales and legends like this one.  

But the movie definitely works when you're watching it; one of the best adventure-thrillers of all time!

Jaws Movie Review
Did you know sharks kill an average of 10 people a year, worldwide?
Now, imagine eight shark kills in a single week!  Yesterday, I watched a Steven Spielberg classic, Jaws. Jaws is about a killer Great White Shark that is attacking swimmers off the coast of a fictional island called Amity, which is off the coast of New England.
The acting is great, with many award winning actors, including Roy Scheider, Richard Dreyfuss, and Robert Shaw.
Roy Sheider plays Martin Brody, the star of the movie, and the local sheriff of Amity. Martin is from New York, but moves to Amity with his family because he feels that in a small town, he has more of an impact on preventing crime.
"'I'm tellin' ya, the crime rate in New York will kill ya. There's so many problems, you never feel like you're accomplishing anything. Violence, rip-offs, muggings. The kids can't leave the house. You gotta walk 'em to school. But in Amity, one man can make a difference. In twenty-five years, there's never been a shooting or a murder in this town." Quote from Martin Brody. 
An ironic detail about Martin Brody is that he is afraid of the water, even though he is the one (spoiler alert!) who kills the shark in the end. 
Richard Dreyfuss plays a leading role as an oceanographer named Matt Hooper, who specializes in sharks, and helps track down the shark.
Robert Shaw plays Quint, a professional shark hunter, who is strange but entertaining. He has a leading role in helping to kill the shark.
The special effects in Jaws were not entirely accurate, but are still exceptionally impressive for a 1975 movie, and can even hold up to today's standards, as well as the rest of the movie.
The suspense in Jaws is incredible, and the ominous, trademark, Jaws soundtrack plays every time the shark goes in for the kill.
In my opinion, Jaws is an absolute masterpiece, because of it's great suspense, colorful characters, and awesomely gory kills. It has an excellent plot, nail biting suspense, and most importantly, never has a dull moment. Jaws is surprisingly scary for such an old movie, and ages like fine wine.

There are certain movies that come along that change everything.  This is one of those films.  A brilliant, engaging, visually frightening, masterpiece of modern horror that changed the genre forever.  Based on Peter Benchley's best selling novel, based on true events, the motion picture managed to capture the imagination of viewers.   Many people refused to go in the water the summer this film came out due to the fear that lingered long after they left the theater.   While many, many films tried to recapture the magic of this one-very few succeeded.  The heart of the film is the acting and the character interplay that was synergistic.   Roy Scheider was made to be the Island Sheriff with a fear of the water.    A young Richard Dreyfuss brought humor and charm to the film.  However, it was Robert Shaw, playing a modern Captain Ahab, that was most memorable.   Spielberg learned, and taught us, that some of the scariest moments can be the anticipation of what is to come, and not necessarily in the gore of an attack scene in horror.   This one holds up.

Jaws is the prime example of what happens when Steven Spielberg and John Williams pair up their masterful minds. The movie opens with one of the scariest first scenes in history, and the shark is never shown. Accompanied by Williams's iconic theme, Spielberg works his magic, and continues that magic for the rest of the film's runtime. The late Roy Scheider nails his role and doesn't shy away from being on screen for the majority of the movie, even improvising a few lines, including the iconic "You're gonna need a bigger boat." Bill Butler uses clever and unique camera tricks to show emotion and place the viewer in the water with Bruce. For Jaws, everything falls into place, creating a memorable masterpiece in cinema history.

The plot has a great white shark is attacking swimmers and boaters off the shores of Amity, which is getting ready for the July 4th tourist weekend.  The police chief (Roy Scheider) wants to close the beach, but the mayor (Murray Hamilton) doesn't want the beaches closed because the town makes all of its money during the summer season.  I had no idea when I started watching this movie that it would have elements of today's pandemic ‚Äì trying to balance health safety versus economy.  It's a main thread in the first hour of the movie and it goes horribly wrong due to poor choices.  I sure hope it does not portend the same for our country's current situation.

Back to the plot.  The police chief is finally allowed to hire a shark hunter (played by the amazing actor Robert Shaw) and they along with a marine biologist (Richard Dreyfuss) head out in search of the man-eating enemy.  The last hour focuses on this great sea adventure, which includes lots of chatter between the three characters and some terrific action sequences.

I have not watched "Jaws" since I was a teenager ‚Äì mainly because I remember the boat scenes where the three main characters were hunting the shark were long, wordy and boring.  I'm sorry I waited this long to watch this movie again because what I find now in my 50s is that Stephen Spielberg knew how to make films although I still found those hunting scenes a bit too long.  In terms of movie making though, early on in the film, Spielberg loves to play with multiple conversations going on at the same time, which I did not recall from watching it back in the 1980s.  It's kind of a nifty technique that brings layers of dialogue to the story.  It was one of his early films, but you can tell he had talent even back then.

"Jaws" is a fairly tense thriller although the mechanical shark does pale in comparison to what today's computer-generated efforts would be able to produce on film.  I thought it would be dated, but a man-eating shark story never really ages.  I wouldn't watch it the night before going to the beach though.  You won't get in the water.

The birth of the summer blockbuster, Jaws is a tense psychological thriller that, for the most part, lives up to the hype. As a story, Jaws is kind of basic. The writing itself takes no real liberties to differentiate it from any other film of the time, but what made Jaws stand out was the way everything is shot. The scenes filmed from the shark's perspective are probably some of the most iconic shots in Hollywood. The shots were so impactful that it changed the way I looked at the movie itself. I started looking at those shots of all those people's bare legs on a beach like it was a restaurant menu. Given the technological boundaries, it's miraculous Spielberg managed to pull a movie like Jaws off. Rather than having the actual Jaws animatronic in every shot, the music and angles of the shot tell the story to the audience. This kind of film making is something missing in modern cinema, and it's a shame that it isn't quite this prominent more often. Another thing that is amazing on the technical side of this movie is the way Spielberg worked around the fact that everything was filmed around water. While this was used to the advantage of the film, it also dragged it back some. While the building of the universe in the first act is made quite well. The way that the protagonists beat the shark is prolonged, eventually, I got somewhat tired of it. This kind of movie where the story is mediocre, but the visual and technical aspects are incredibly impactful is the summer blockbuster at its core. While the story was just okay, it's important to understand how important Jaws is to the history of film making.

Jaws

Director: Steven Spielberg
Writer: Peter Benchley, Carl Gottlieb
Actor: Roy Schneider, Robert Shaw, Richard Dreyfuss, Lorraine Gary

The movie takes place over the long 4th July holiday weekend on a small island called Amity Island located in the New England region. The Chief of Police Brody (Roy Schneider) and the Mayor Shaw (Murray Hamilton) are in conflict over whether or not to close the beach due to a recent shark attack. The mayor wins the argument to keep the beach open only for another attack to happen and the adventure begins. As the movie continues more and more attacks happen and the Chief Brody takes matters in his own hand and begins to put together a team that can help him pursue this elusive shark that is threatening the residents and vacationers to this island. The Chief was able to convince a shark expert Hopper (Richard Dreyfuss) and a lifelong shark hunter Quint (Robert Shaw) to go along with him to hunt down this menace once and for all and take the shark out. In this hunt we see how focused the Chief has become and when he lays eyes on what he is dealing with face to face the real adventure begins. He then realizes he has a formidable adversary and it's going to take a lot more than he thought to take down this creature
The success of this movie was due immensely to its time of release and it opened in over 400 movie theaters, up until now no movie had ever opened with such preview buzz thus creating the first of the "blockbuster" type movie. This movie was able to take something that is very likely to happen and heighten our awareness of what could happen. This was one of the first movies to take a real set of circumstances and placing man with animal just by going to on vacation and taking a swim. 
The music and the cinematography played a huge role and letting the audience know just how scary of a creature we were about to encounter up close and personal. The placement of the music within the film was excellent. The music has gone down as one of the most recognizable scores in the history of film. Spielberg put his signature in this film when he created this music that only works with this film. This movie kick started Spielberg's career as one of the top grossing directors in Hollywood and went on to be one of the biggest top grossing films of all time.

‚ÄòJaws' is a thriller film directed by Steven Spielberg. It is based on the novel of the same name by Peter Benchley.
Even for the time it came out this movie is still entertaining as hell. It's not the most realistic take on a shark, but it tells a revenge story that keeps you engaged.
In the film, a giant great white shark attacks beachgoer at a New England summer resort town, prompting police chief Martin Brody (Roy Scheider) to hunt it with the help of a marine biologist (Richard Dreyfuss) and a professional shark hunter (Robert Shaw).
You can't say anything bad about the acting in this movie, especially from the main cast. I was surprised by that given the age of the film. There are only a select few films that I consider both classics and to have good acting.
Spielberg brilliantly took what could have been a cheesy movie and turned it into a classic that will never be forgotten. Between the acting, directing and the amazing score, this movie is one to be talked about for years to come still.
Overall, this is yet another master craft from one of the greatest filmmakers out there. Nobody can walk away from watching this movie thinking it could have been better.

Where do I begin? Jaws was the first summer blockbuster- the film that heralded the start of an amazing career of young Steven Spielberg and the one film that single handedly caused beaches to close down that summer. Jaws has two villains. During the first half of the film, the enemy isn't the shark; it's the face of bureaucracy, as personified by the mayor. More concerned with the economic bottom line than with the possibility of someone being injured, Vaughn muzzles Martin, allowing further deaths to occur. While Martin battles Vaughn and his puppets on the town council, the shark lurks in the background, ready to take over the role of antagonist when the mayor gives way. The second half of the film is the classic man against beast, with Jaws representing the rarest of movie monsters - something that exists in the depths of the ocean (albeit typically in smaller dimensions). This, of course, is the clash for which people watch the movie, and it is handled with great skill.

While I appreciate the historical importance of this film I don't think it holds up to today's entertainment standards and I do not think it is one of the greatest films of all time. Director Steven Spielberg is of course famous for directing countless classic popcorn thrillers with Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977) and Raiders of the Lost Ark (1981) being among the films on his resume. This was the film that launched it all however as it was a smash hit, even earning a Best Picture nomination, after the minimal success of The Sugarland Express (1974). This is not one of my favorite films of 1975 as I prefer Nashville (1975) and Barry Lyndon (1975) but it was certainly the biggest financial hit of the summer.

On the small island of Amity, hard-nosed police chief Martin Brody, Roy Scheider, begins investigating a case in which a local woman was killed by a shark. He is urged to suppress information about the attack due to the fear that it will hurt the local economy by cutting down the amount of tourism. The shark continues to attack people as tensions rise and Brody teams up with well educated shark hunting enthusiast Matt Hooper, Richard Dreyfuss. The public becomes interested in the case and professional hunter Quint, Robert Shaw, offers to kill the shark for payment. The men all head off together in an attempt to kill the shark and although they initially do not jell they eventually find common ground and are able to take down the shark.

My biggest issue with almost all films of this type in which we are meant to delight in the gore produced by a vicious villain, in this case a shark, are that the humans being killed by them are lacking in dimension and are therefore very difficult to care about. It's not that Scheider, Dreyfuss and Shaw have not given fantastic performances in other films but they have so little work with here that it is hard to see them as characters worth investing in. I was unaffected by the sight of random teenagers being ravaged by a shark both because the sight was a little bit ridiculous and because I had no reason to care. At the end of the film I didn't feel like I knew who these characters were and the fact that they survived didn't make me feel triumphant in the way that it should have because they were just a collection of ideas rather than fully formed human beings we could relate to in their terror.

The most appealing parts of the film come when we see them battle the shark as the score is magnificent, the sequence in which they try to capture the shark is well shot and some of the best lines pop up here. I would argue that the film doesn't do as good a job at setting up as it should as when comparing it to another film that fits into the horror genre and spends the majority of it's time building up suspense, The Shining (1980), I was utterly bored during the first half of the film. All of the technical elements of the film receive recognition and deservingly so because they are impressive now and would have been even more so in 1975 when it was so far ahead of most films of it's type being released.

Had I seen this film in 1975 I would have been more impressed by it as entertainment of it's type would not have previously existed in the form that it does now and I would not have been able to anticipate all of the plot beats. Sure, the film still excites at some moments and it's special effects still stand out as being groundbreaking but I found myself bored more often than not and that left me with time to ponder the shortcomings of the film which lowered it's status in my mind. A film does suffer over time as even one as famous and acclaimed as this doesn't necessarily connect with audiences 44 years later who are so familiar with the media that it has inspired and for me I have to say that I was underwhelmed.

American auteur Steven Spielberg's horror adventure thriller Jaws (1975) holds up even half a century later! Jaws broke new ground as the first blockbuster and it's simply a thrill ride of a massive shark eating swimmers off a beach by a coastal town for 4th of July season. It really is the best movie to watch on Independence Day every year. Endlessly rewatchable and considerably scarier than many modern horror pictures that have tried and failed to capture the fear of what lurks in deep waters compared to Jaws. Producers Richard D. Zanuck and David Brown helped Spielberg get Jaws made through much documented troubles from getting funding for a fish film to making the enormous physical shark puppet. Steven Spielberg came out the gate swinging with his first major success for his ambitious Jaws. He establishes likable characters with their own flaws and fears before they ever go after the shark.  Jaws may be Spielberg's finest film.

Spielberg's direction is fascinating. Spielberg relies on a magnificent mechanical shark puppet that looks genuinely real to this day. Jaws is all the more scary because of Spielberg trying to do things practically and creatively. He only hints at a shark being present and then stuns you with reveals of teeth and corpses to Jaws fully lunging onto shark to wreak havoc. His love of stories about fatherhood works wonders for Jaws. Brody is a police chief, but also wants to play with his son, yet harshly scolds him and abandons his family on one level to go after the shark. 

Spielberg's entire filmography is all about fatherhood, parenting, and abandonment issues. Jaws sets all that up beautifully. Spielberg lets you get to know this coastal police chief with a childhood trauma that leads to his fear of water, an eager oceanographer with a childhood fascination with sharks, a salty sea captain with a lust for fishing giant fish at all costs, to the greedy mayor thinking only of profits over the lives of his citizens and visitors getting eaten in shark infested waters.

Roy Scheider is fantastic as calm and rational Police Chief Martin Brody. His increasingly paranoid fear of the shark is hilarious, while he is also sympathetic as he's merely trying to keep his town and family safe. Scheider plays a loving husband, tough police chief, politely mannered, and endearing horror hero. Roy is a genius actor. I love watching Scheider portray Brody. I will go to my grave saying Roy Scheider should have gotten an Oscar nomination for Best Actor for Jaws.

Richard Dreyfuss' cocky scientist Matt Hooper is funny with his cavalier personality and cathartic frustrations with ignorant locals and officials not listening to science. His young confident sailor and aspiring scientist with shark expertise is a fabulous foil for Robert Shaw. Shaw's surly fisherman Quint with his rough aesthetic and crazy personality is captivating. His monologue about the U.S.S. Indianapolis' sailing crew getting eaten by sharks before his eyes is haunting. Shaw is likable despite his hardened manner and blunt speech. He should have gotten an Oscar honestly for Jaws.

Murray Hamilton's cowardly Mayor Larry Vaughn is so funny and pathetic as he callously lets his citizenry and vacationers die on his watch. Lorraine Gary is very nice, supportive, and concerned as Roy's wife Ellen Brody. Lee Fierro is quite moving as Mrs. Kintner, who loses her son. I'm always stunned when she confronts Chief Brody since he kept the beaches open even after knowing a young lady was killed by a shark a week prior.

Visually, Jaws is probably Spielberg's most striking picture. From the interesting fast zoom to a close-up shot of Roy Scheider's shocked facial expression on the beach after a shark attack to the beautiful backdrop of calm waters that are hiding a dangerous aquatic predator. Jaws is so stylish and cool. Cinematographer Bill Butler gets creative with when he'll just show a shark fin, Jaws' face, or his entire fish body. I like how the camera often takes the shark's perspective in the water approaching a boat or victim. He builds suspense from the water to the ports. He uses all these enthralling close-ups as the actors get to monologue that really captivated me. I always love when films focus on their characters rather than just the story.

Bestselling novelist Peter Benchley is the author of his book Jaws as well as the screenplay writer for Spielberg's film. I love Benchley's deep characterizations of these men with their own strong personalities and defined motivations for seeking out this shark. A police chief trying to protect his community, a father protecting his family, as well as Brody wants to redeem himself out of guilt after allowing a little boy to get eaten by Jaws when he kept the beaches open at the mayor's demand. I like Benchley harshly critiquing the cowardly mayor's politicking and profiteering as the bodies pile up for fish food. Benchley's social commentary is brilliant in Jaws.

I appreciate that Benchley later regretted writing Jaws as it created the social hysteria to kill sharks en masse and be afraid of these majestic creatures of the sea. He kindly became a shark conservationist to help keep sharks alive and not endangered. Screenplay writer Carl Gottlieb helped adapt Jaws with knowledge of scuba diving, fishing, and marine life besides compelling dramatic storytelling. There's even a progressive science and fact based rationale versus the superstitions and local hysteria on a thematic level. What a fantastic story Jaws is with scary shark sightings and attacks like we've never seen before or since Jaws nailed it. These relatable characters ground Jaws on land before we set out to sea in search of sharks. Jaws' real scares, colorful characters, startling direction, and charismatic acting lead to it remaining a timeless horror thriller. It is part social commentary, while ending up a full blown horror film. Jaws knows how to establish its world quickly and thoroughly, then blast you with fearsome imagery.

Composer John Williams wrote a legendary score for Jaws. His tense music is practically another character. It sets the tone for each moment. From his half step main theme for Jaws to his explosive rush of melodies for the visceral shark attacks. You will be on the edge of your seat as Williams' symphony tears into you like Jaws himself. Williams shows you what less is more means when his simplistic yet effective score chimes in suddenly. Jaws' score contributes intensity and atmosphere. John Williams' compositions for Jaws are as iconic and scary as horror movie soundtracks get. Sound designers John R. Carter and Robert L. Hoyt creates water flowing sound effects to the shark biting down or loudly ramming the ship noises to add to Jaws' fearsome nature.

Editor Verna Fields's sharp cuts keeps the world's first blockbuster afloat and enthralling for 124 minutes of aquatic horror with one giant fish alongside compelling human drama. Going from the shark perspective to the victim is a neat editing choice that defines Jaws' cutting edge style. The conversations are cut to let the actors simply talk without incessant cuts, then scenes will hard cut to a new shark attack or worried townsfolk. Jaws is creatively cut at a brisk pace that makes it feel like it's like a half hour long.

Production designer Joe Alves made cinema's greatest practical puppet effect with the mechanical shark Bruce to be the movie shark Jaws. The small town sets look very natural. Set decorator John M. Dwyer adorns the fishing vessels that have realistic equipment everywhere for hunting down sharks at sea. Make-up artists Del Armstrong and Jim Gillespie's make-up gives Robert Shaw gritty tattoos and a mustache, while Roy Scheider is clean cut like his character and Richard Dreyfuss is just a bit scruffy.

The acting is so believable and likable with Roy Scheider, Robert Shaw, and Richard Dreyfuss leading a thankless fishing voyage to hunt down Jaws. You get to know each of their characters, motives, and personalities. Jaws contains as charismatic a cast as you will ever see.

Give Jaws a watch during a bright Summer day, then see if you will ever want to visit a beach again.

The debut blockbuster, Jaws, invaded U.S cinemas forty years ago today. The PG rated, 124 minute fear factor feature adaptation novel immediately caught the film-going audiences in 75. 
Universal's Jaws swallowed instant success at the box-office, with $260,000,000 unadjusted domestic gross and a staggering $1,173,202,000 adjusted domestic gross. 
Possibly the most well constructed horror story in cinematic history, having the actual Great White appear just over half way into the motion picture. Its dooming presence is established in the opening sequence as it takes the life of Susan Backlinie.
All three characters are perfectly set-up and have well balanced screentime. Captain Martin Brody (Roy Scheider) is Amity's police chief, and he is the one who reacts in the same way audience do, petfrified of the waters and concerned for the people of Amity Island. We genuinely feel sympathy for him when he is publicly shamed by Mrs. Kintner from the loss of her child, blaming Brody for his death. This brings us to the character Larry Vaughn, the Mayor of Amity Island and pressures Brody to keep the beaches open for the 4th July, ending in disaster as Micheal Brody ends up hospital from the shock of seeing a man eaten by the shark. Then there is Quint (Robert Shaw), the intimidating but comedic with his witty lines such as, "Half assed astronaut" to Hooper and "I saw one eat a rocking chair once." The man ex-navy marine has a good heart and has a hatred for sharks. My favourite character is next, Hooper (Richard Dreyfuss), the witty scientist is the perfect example of a well rounded person. As he is the shark expert and bring fear into the audience as we see him terrified of the aftermath of Susan Backlinie. The chemistry of all three characters really come together when they are on the Orca and are hunting the killing machine. Especially the chemistry between Hooper and Quint butting heads of old vs new theme. But, then bonding when sharing scars from past shark attacks and all three men singing together. 
The direction Spielberg chooses to go is without question perfect with the pacing not being too slow or too fast. The gradual build of tension throughout the motion picture pays off with the final battle with Brody and the man eating shark. 
Of course the score has to be mentioned with the great John Williams orchestrating it. Probably the most known theme in cinema, the film wouldn't be the same without the intensifying and sinister tone. It supports the film perfectly whenever the shark was on and off the camera. 
Overall Jaws is in my top five of Spielberg's filmography. The classic blockbuster will always be remembered as a monument in the horror genre.

Set in the 1970's, Jaws tells the story of a small east-coast town whose world turns upside down as its people continue to be picked off one by one. The story follows the town's chief as he investigates the source of the issue. Through watching the film, I found myself thoroughly enjoying it quite a bit more than I anticipated. Jaws didn't fail to let me down in terms of suspense and surprise, and that was thanks to the editing.  I feel that this was especially achieved in the pacing of the editing. Editor Verna Fields does a great job at drawing out each shot to build tension and to create and further the suspense. This is evidenced in a particular scene that takes place at the beach. The chief of police has just discovered that a great white shark has caused the initial death on the beach. In his attempt to shut down the beach, the town's mayor, who insists on keeping the beach open regardless, intercepts him. In the scene, the chief is on edge as he keeps watch of the beach's attendees. The scene cuts between different drawn out shots of those attendees as we wait in impatience for the potential impending threat. I found myself constantly on edge as I watched through these moments. The payoff of the scene being executed the way that it was were those great moments of surprise when the shark would finally surface and take on its next prey. I watched the film with some friends of mine, and we would literally jump out of our seats every time this would happen. One thing that I particularly enjoyed was that in the scenes that the shark made an appearance in, even though you knew the shark was coming, you were still surprised when it materialized.

He is paired up with shark expert Hooper (Richard Dreyfuss).  Upon discovering that they're dealing with a rather large great white shark, they have a hard time convincing the clueless mayor (Murray Hamilton) that they need to take serious measures to stop the predator.  It's not until another shark attack on a beach crowded with tourists that they hire local fisherman Quint (Robert Shaw) to kill the shark.  Soon the three men board Quint's boat to take down the shark and it's tense action from then on.
Based on the book by Peter Benchley, there are a lot of changes made for the film but you may not care because it's so well paced and put together.  Due to reported production issues, we don't see the shark a whole lot but Spielberg made it work through John Williams' famous score.  For me it made sense because the shark does look fake.  The performances are wonderful, the script is well written and the characters are developed and interesting.  Even better, the action in the third and forth acts is exciting and tense.  A terrific film that I highly recommend.

Steven Spielberg's classic film about a giant shark terrorizing a small New England resort community is masterful entertainment and also (along with "Star Wars") ushered in the age of the blockbuster film, essentially ending major studio support of smaller edgier films of the 1960s and 70s. I recently listened to an interview with Roger Corman, the prolific low budget exploration filmmaker, who noted that after he saw "Jaws" he said to himself that he's in trouble because the majors figured out what he'd know for years, in terms of what audiences wanted to see, and did it much better. An argument could pretty easily be made that this is the greatest nature-gone-wild movie ever made. "Jaws" truly is a great film, but when most of it's competition was the the likes of "Frogs" (about a deadly hoards of frogs)  or "Them" (about giant radioactive ants) or "Night of the Lepus" (about giant killer rabbits), it shouldn't be much of a surprise "Jaws" wins out (okay, Hitchcock's "The Birds" is a pretty excellent nature-gone-wild film, but "Jaws" is still better). But back to "Jaws," this is the film that put Spielberg on the map. Up to this point he'd mostly done television and had one film under his belt, the fine "Sugarland Express," but "Jaws" is a popcorn movie of the first order. Roy Scheider is the Chief of Police for the sleepy beach community of Amity Island when he's confronted with a likely shark attack at the outset of tourist season. Murray Hamilton is great in a supporting role as the mayor who won't let Chief Brody shut down the beaches, that is until a horrific attack in front of legions of beachgoers. At that point Brody is authorized to enlist the help of young shark expert Matt Hooper (Richard Dreyfuss) and crusty shark hunter Quint (Robert Shaw). Brody, Hooper, and Quint are a wonderful trio of contrasts aboard Quint's ship as they hunt the giant great white shark. One early exchange between Hooper and Quint quickly sums up their relationship:

Quint: You have city hands, Mr. Hooper. You been countin' money all your life. 
Hooper: All right, all right. Hey, I don't need this... I don't need this working-class-hero crap.

And you have Brody, who lives on an island but doesn't ever go in the water, playing the level headed one of the trio who wants to be anywhere but on a boat. The character dynamics between the three are terrific fun to watch and lead to many memorable scenes and quips ("You're gonna need a bigger boat." or "Cage goes in the water, you go in the water. Shark's in the water." or "Slow ahead. I can go slow ahead. Come on down here and chum some of this sh-t." or "I'm not going to waste my time arguing with a man who's lining up to be a hot lunch." and then there's the USS Indianapolis speech. Quint's tale (and character motivation) is a perfect marriage of acting, writing, and direction and is likely my favorite scene of the film. Robert Shaw is absolutely riveting as he tells his tale of his WWII naval vessel going down after being hit by Japanese submarine torpedoes and the men having to survive for days in the water as sharks preyed upon them.  "I'll never put on a life jacket again." There's been much discussion as to who wrote this scene, but according to Spielberg it was first written by playwright Howard Sackler, who wrote about three quarters of a page, and was then expanded by the great John Milius to about ten pages of dialogue, and lastly Shaw himself pared down Milius' work to what appears in the film. This has to be one of the all-time greatest moments committed to film. But the suspense Spielberg builds towards the end as the ship is slowing sinking while the three men struggle to figure out how to kill the shark and/or how to survive. The way the camera bobs up and down with the waves and how the camera gets lower and lower into the water as the boat slowly sinks is extremely effective in immersing the audience in the situation, especially if you've seen this film in a darkened theater on the big screen, where you nearly feel Brody's sea sickness, not to mention his terror as the shark gets closer and closer. But as fun this film is as a rollercoaster thrill ride, you also can't forget the quieter moments, such as the dinner table scene where Brody and his son silently mimic each other, which audiences would later realize is a moment of pure Spielberg. Or the smaller comic moments early in the film with Broday taking reports of kids from the karate class "karate chopping" the fences, perfectly establishing Chief Brody's usual police activities. Jaws is no doubt one of the most iconic movies of all time and a prominent part of our cultural literacy. How many variations of "We're going to need a bigger boat." have you seen or heard in your everyday life? It is easy to see why Jaws became the first big summer blockbuster film. The visual effects still hold up even with today's standards. If you pause the film, you may be able to see how fake the mechanical shark actually looks, but combined with Spielberg's masterful camera work, he has been able to fool audiences for decades. However, it isn't the shark that makes the film so great, but the lack thereof. The shark isn't actually shown until halfway through the movie, keeping audiences on the edge of their seats. An invisible enemy combined with the iconic soundtrack by John Williams creates an aura of suspense that is palpable.
The scene that really makes this movie memorable is the speech delivered by Quint to Hooper and Chief Brody out on the Orca after comparing scars and sharing drinks. He describes the weeks he spent floating in the sea after the Indianapolis sank, watching his crewmates get eaten by swarming sharks. Throughout the movie Quint is your stereotypical sea captain, singing sea shanties and drinking almost nothing but booze. Robert Shaw's stony faced, slightly slurred delivery is remarkable, horrifying the audience just as much as it horrified Hooper and Brody. This speech reveals to us why Quint is the way he is while making his death that much more ironic. The thing that has haunted him for most of his life is what ultimately ends up killing him.

The tension created in Jaws is unlike others. Even without showing the shark for almost half the movie, Spielberg is still able to successfully instill fear in the audience. The iconic "dun uh -dun uh -dun-dun-dun-dun" (which you probably just hummed to yourself while reading), lets viewers know exactly what is about to happen. We do not need to see a civilian getting ripped to shreds to be scared. The music itself is enough to send a chill throughout viewer's' bodies. One of the scariest parts is how ordinary all of the victims are. This allows the viewer's to connect and sympathize more with the characters, and makes it feel more realistic. The movie is relatable to teens, for it is so normal for younger people to hang out on the beach at night. As a teenage viewer, I have now learned that I never want to go swimming at night. It is also relatable for adults, pulling on the heartstrings when little Alex is attacked, almost forcing parents to imagine themselves in the same position. Regardless of age, this movie will make everyone feel uneasy at some point. 
	I believe this is one of those movies where you pick up on something new every time you watch. The first time, I never would have guessed that the tank would result in the shark's demise. The second time, I wondered how I had totally missed that. As I had learned in film appreciation, every part of a story is important. There are numerous shots that focus on the tank, just filming it laying there for a few seconds, which seems very out of place. In reality, Spielberg was completely foreshadowing the importance the tank would play in the killing of the great white. This movie contains so many little details that can easily be overlooked, but when noticed, just adds more to the creative genius that is Jaws.

Jaws is considered to be one of the greatest movies ever made and it is easy to see why.  When it came out to be a horror movie in 1975 it is surprising to think that after watching it, there was more to this film than you could have expected from the title and poster of the movie.  There are many examples to why this was as great as it came out to be one being that it is considered to be the first ever "summer blockbuster" making way for other films to come and rack up the big bucks during the summer seasons.  Second is it's impacted on pop culture, as you can see countless references to the movie in your favorite TV shows, radio stations, and other movies as well. The movie has remained a spectacle today and holds up as well and here is why.
When the script was first bought by Universal Studios in 1973, the producers didn't know what to make of it.  It was a script that was ready to go into production but they couldn't find the right director or cast for the picture.  Once the producers landed on a young director, Steven Spielberg, they were 100% ready for production and had the leading cast of Roy Scheider, Robert Shaw, and Richard Dreyfuss ready to go.  The film was finished and production was considered hell.  Many script changes, malfunctions with the mechanical sharks, and actors having fights with each other.  Many of the film crew were surprised by how the film came out including Steven Spielberg.  Spielberg said, "I thought this was the beginning of the end of my career, this production continues to haunt me today."  But once Jaws hit theater in 1975 people were waiting in lines out of the theatre to go in see it, it became a worldwide phenomenon making $470,653,000 worldwide.  Viewers were hooked by this film and it easy to see why.

Similar to what Arachnophobia and Psycho do to showering, Jaws causes you to want to stay on the nice dry beach, far far away from the water's edge this summer. Opened in 1975, Jaws has continued to invoke a psychological fear from the moment Spielberg decided to start his opening scenes off with a girl being attacked by a shark and escalated to a full scale shark attack on the weekend of 4th of July, all leading up to the final man-to-shark battle at the conclusion of the film. 

	This film is split into two sections- the "before" the shark is seen, and the "after". The "before" part is prior to when Spielberg allows us the pleasure of seeing the much alluded shark. He builds up the idea of 'evil' and 'enemy' with his other characters to go along with the suspense that his film is building up, so we don't even really notice that the shark is missing in a sense. He was able to build this up in his music choices. This "evil" is seen in the mayor (Murry Hamilton) along with the town council, when they refuse to close down the beach even after the first death, because they don't want to lose the town money. Without his stamp of approval, further deaths occurred and he is eventually forced to admit that something must be done about the shark problem. 

The shark itself we only see in fleeting and distant sightings, none of which satisfy our desire to see the beast. In the final 20 minutes of the film, do we actually get a full length shot of the creature- and then we see the reason behind Spielberg's non inclusion of the animal- it looks fake. But in retrospect, we did not even need to see it in the earlier moments of the film, since Spielberg's cuts and inclusion of suspenseful music allowed us to have a growing sense of fear and doom anyway.
	
	The end was, in my opinion, a plot twist. There was the defeat of the deadly beast- but there was also the death of a ruthless character we had grown to love- a tragic death at that. There have been many movies that have attempted to replicate this film, and many more that have created spoofs, but nothing will ever be able to compete with Spielberg's work.

A pioneer for modern suspense techniques, Steven Spielberg's film Jaws, remains the greatest and uncontested summer beach blockbuster of all time.  Even those who have not had the pleasure of watching it know of the famous theme song as the shark slices through the water to reach the next victim. Even more outstanding, the suspense that Jaws created for horror movies to come was by chance. The way the events unfold throughout the movie directly correlate to a broken down mechanical shark and it is not until halfway through the plot that the viewer finally meets Jaws once and for all. For this reason, Spielberg has a unique chance, one that he masterfully uses, of adding an element of mystery to the plot. Often time's before the shark attacks, the viewer gets a high angled shot onto the legs of possible victims before he makes his final move and effectively gives the killer a point of view. One of the most impactful and gruesome uses of this shot is when little Alex Kintner and his yellow float are chose as the next victim and all the viewer sees is a fountain of blood. For some, Jaws hit so close to home that they were repelled by the thought of swimming in the ocean, much less to dip a toe in to feel the water's temperature.
One of the most iconic lines in Jaws is when Matt Hooper says, "What we are dealing with here is a perfect engine, an eating machine. It's really a miracle of evolution. All this machine does is swim and eat and make little sharks, and that's all." This line perfectly encapsulates the essence of the shark and it nonexistent "humanity" and instead refers to it as a machine without thought or feeling. However, this quote also serves to heighten the stories of the people on land, specifically Chief Brody This film may be mistaken for the typical horror bloodbath, yet it works hard to be anything but. This is a story of tragedy, of family, and of humanity.  To make sure that the audience understood this, Speilberg added the scene when Brody and his son are sitting at the dinner table. Chief Brody did what was simply evolutionary expected of him when he made "little sharks" yet there is a difference between him and Jaws. When his son starts copying him it shows a clear human and emotional connection that any parent viewing it could relate to. "Give your old man a kiss," Chief Brody says with affection. This is a film about people just as much as it is about a murderous shark. This film is effective in conveying the love and loss between characters and developing their lives. It expertly manipulates the viewer to laugh one second and to feel hopeless the next. Jaws will always be the classic beach movie that is watched the week prior to Memorial Day Weekend to entice the nostalgia and appropriate fear as people head off to swim in the lovely blue sea.

Jaws is one of the most terrifying monster movies ever made, yet it has less than 10 minutes of the monster on screen. The shark is not the monster, it is the ingenious music and the tense atmosphere that cause us to dread the creature.  However, the shark itself is not even a looming threat until the second half of the film, as the first half and even a majority of the second half are dedicated to the characters. That is why this film holds up even 42 years later, because Spielberg knew to create memorable, likable, interesting characters that hold our attention when the shark is not devouring helpless people. He knew to use the shark sparingly, he knew to turn the shark into an entity with John williams brilliant score, he knew to make every kill different  and every scare unique. Spielberg knew that gore and a cool monster wouldn't make a great film, he used the subtlety of a film like Haunted House with the tone/feel of a modern day summer film to create a truly unique and wonderful movie. 
The shark is not scary, it's not a very creative design nor does the animatronic look very realistic, but Jaws is terrifying. We almost always see the shark with a point of view shot, giving us a sense of helplessness as we see move through a sea of legs and close in on it's prey. We know what will happen, yet we can only dread the inevitable as the camera cruelly and slowly moves to its target. The music builds up slowly, gradually, going from creating ominous dread to heart-pounding terror right before the kill. Another thing that makes the shark terrifying when it is on screen is the fact that every scare is done in a different way. Unlike a Friday the 13th film or Elm street sequel, where every kill is just an over the top gore fest, every time someone dies it is different. For example, when the teenage girl gets attacked to the shark, we our are cruelly subjected to see almost every minute of her death, hearing every scream and cry, paralyzing us with fear. Yet the Kittner boy's death is completely different, we merely see the mass of blood in the water, and the bitten life raft, making this death more shocking than letting the tragedy come in when The mother calls out for her son in vain. The different methods Spielberg employes to make the shark scary prevents the creature from becoming predictable, keeping the audience on it's toes. However, we are never bored when the shark is off screen, as the main characters are some of the best in blockbuster history. 
The writers of this film knew that having a scary monster is not enough to engage an audience or make a film last, so it seems they dedicated more time in making these characters interesting, memorable, likable, and relatable. They succeeded, as years latter we still quote Quint, Hooper, and Martin Brody and even remember the some of the side characters like Ellen and the Mayor. I think what separates these characters from the Jurassic Park-esque stock characters (which can be entertaining in their own right) is that cast is not overly large. We only have 3 main characters in Jaws and primarily follow one, as opposed to something like Lost World, Which starts with out with 5 main characters. Because of the relatively small cast, our main trio get much more focus and are able to be fleshed out in a more natural way. There are no long, Shyamalan style expostion monologues explaining the characters to us, we simply watch the characters. We are introduced to Brody by seeing his family life and average routine, We see Hooper mocking the shark hunters and how he does his job, and we gradually see Quint go from unhinged sailor to insane hunter. The film lets us grow attached to these characters, allows the audience to form a connection with them, become invested in them. Brody, Hooper, and Quint personality feel organic and fresh, allowing from some fun and interesting interactions. My favorite is the relationship between Quint and Hooper, as their polar opposite personalities bounce off each other in some brilliant scenes. Quint's rough, old fashioned, and violent personality clashes with both Hooper's jumpy, sarcastic persona and reserved and scientific approach. Yet despite their passionate arguments, Hooper seems to have a desire to prove himself to Quint or best him. This perfectly exemplified when Quint crushes and empty can,  and Hooper crushes a plastic cup in response. You could show someone this scene and they would instantly get an idea of what these characters are like and how they work off each other. Brody, Hooper, and Quint are the reason why Jaws is a great film, they are the reason we watch this film over and over again. When they are not on screen, the hybrid of slow cinematography and intense music known the characters refer to as a shark keep on the edge of our seats. This is why Jaws is the greatest horror film ever made, one of the greatest blockbusters ever made, and a cinematic masterpiece.

That slow, looming bass riff that encompasses the theme of the movie has long since been the source of my hydrophobia ever since I was a kid. The ever-prevalent despair when some poor unfortunate and naive actor wanders into the water and you know what's coming, but there is nothing you can do about it. That is true horror-movie fear, and Jaws has plenty of that. Much of the fear of the movie comes from the fact that you rarely ever actually wind up seeing the shark that is spoken of often throughout the film. It mimics reality as well, as you will rarely see a shark before it takes a chomp out of you.

There's only one movie that people credit with making them too scared to swim in the ocean or even the pool in their backyard. Steven Spielberg's "Jaws" took the film industry by storm when it was released in 1975. Its simple yet terrifying theme song, which remains iconic to this day, was ranked 6th on the American Film Institute's 100 Years of Film Scores. Spielberg brilliantly combines this music with underwater traveling shots to create tension as the audience sees the world from the shark's point of view. It's impossible to know when the shark is going to strike, thus striking fear into the audience. Despite major production issues that almost left "Jaws" half eaten and washed up on the shore, "Jaws" became the highest grossing film of its time.

 Being loosely based off of a book written by Peter Benchley, Spielberg created a horrifyingly realistic representation of Benchley's made up world in which a small town has a powerful, man-eating shark on its hands. Some may say the effort put into creating a giant, mechanical shark was not worth the final outcome because it didn't give the most convincing performance. However, by not allowing audiences to see the shark until the second half of the film, Spielberg retains some of its flare. The effects used to make it look as though the shark is pulling three barrels underwater or slowly swimming underneath the boat give off the appearance that they are dealing with not only a strong, but a smart beast. Supplemented with real shark footage as well, "Jaws" holds more than enough of a fear factor to keep anyone's feet dry, at least until they watch its sequels.

The film Jaws created by effects genius Steven Spielberg, and was based off of the book written by Peter Benchley, and took the film world by storm in 1975. The movie was one of the firsts of its kind because it basically became the first summer blockbuster setting a precedent on what one looked like. In my opinion Jaws is a nearly flawless film that takes the viewer on an interesting journey starting with a couple of attacks on people, to a full fledged manhunt to take down the shark. There are many things that make this film so great; the way that Spielberg does not show the shark for the first half of the film, the amazing portrayals of the three main characters that go on the shark hunt, and finally the story of the film is perfect and flows beautiful. 
There is so much suspense and tension built up over the course of the first half of the film with the viewer in the point of the shark. By doing this it creates the actual horror of the shark attacking people without actually showing the full shark, and when they show the shark in pursuit of its victims all that is seen is his dorsal fin. This technique further adds to the suspense of an attack, and then they finally build all of this up to the full reveal of the shark whilst the men are hunting it. Next the portrayal of the three main characters is perfect, and they each add a key element to the film that is essentially irreplaceable. The first character we meet is Roy Scheider's "Matt Brody" the local police chief who works on the island and is afraid of water. That little detail is completely ironic because in a shark hunt he is going to need to be on a boat in the water, and that just adds further to his character development. The next character that is introduced is actually Robert Shaw's "Quint", but we don't completely get his story until the actual shark hunt because he is only in the one scene to announce he'll kill the shark. Therefore the next character made known is Richard Dreyfuss "Matt Hooper" who is a rich-kid marine biologist who is there to study the shark and help bring it down. He provides a perfect foil to "Quint" as they butt heads on the boat(and the set), making their character dynamics an interesting one to follow. After "Hooper" is introduced the audience gets to meet the real "Quint" as they begin their journey to kill the shark. This is when we see "Quint" in his element being the hard nosed, ex-military man who has the "his way or the highway mentality", and is arguably the best character in this film. Seeing the three characters together on the boat and the way they interact with one another is phenomenal they add depth to the film.

Jaws is a fantastic film that uses technology in a way unknown to its time. This technology is truly shown through the shark. The shark, from the point of view of the audience, looks as if it is actually a real shark. In reality, the shark is made from machinery and technology and in its full form does not look too realistic. Spielberg is able to deal with this by using specific camera angles that make the shark have the effect that it does. Furthermore, when Spielberg portrays the shark, he often does it in a way that does not even show the shark. This is done through a point of view shot through the eyes of what is thought to be the shark. The audience, in fact, knows that it is the shark through the classic music played as the shark approaches a person.
Also, aside from the shark, Spielberg does a great job on his film through the tension and shift in mood. This movie quickly moves through highs and lows. The film often quickly switches from a peaceful mood to a high tension dark mood. This is done through the sound and effects. When the mood is peaceful, all the audience can hear is laughter, splashing, and kids playing. This is while you see the bright sun and bright colors around the beach. This mood quickly changes when the cut goes to the shark with the high tension music approaching a person. After each attack, the water turns red and there is no more screaming. There is only screaming and running of the people.

As a relatively young film viewer and critic, I was newly exposed to Steven Spielberg's Jaws last year. Since Jaws has a huge fan base and is the most notorious shark film, I already had an idea of the plot. However, knowing what was going to happen before I saw the film and knowing it was created more than two decades before I was even born, Spielberg still created one of the most memorable works of cinematography. When I was a kid, I remember being out in the ocean and my older cousin imitating the music that corresponded to the shark. Even at a young age I knew what the music signified, a shark. 
	After seeing Jaws for the first time last year, I really enjoyed the movie and was happy to have finally watched it. I have just watched it for a second time a week ago and the movie was just as good or even better than it was before. A huge scene that makes this movie for me is the Indianapolis Speech that Quint delivers. The whole time the crew of men are showing their battle wounds and sharing a good laugh, as a viewer I feel like I am on the boat with them and it's a typical night out at sea, void of problems. As Quint begins his speech, his speech captivates the audience and causes me to hold my breath. Quint is this strong, fearless, confident fisherman throughout the whole film. Once he reaches the speech we see a more vulnerable side of him, showing the similarities the three men actually have with their caution towards sharks and the ocean around them. His speech shows a huge turning point in the atmosphere and foreshadows a possible death the men can face as no one can reach them out at sea just like the Indianapolis.
	Overall, the movie is perfectly structured with each scene having a purpose that drives the plot and makes the film a huge success.

Duh duh, duh duh; we all know that famous soundtrack by John Williams that leaves us haunted by the depths of the ocean, the anticipation is the scare and that is utilized by Stephen Spielberg in his movie "Jaws". For a movie in 1975, the effects were astounding, blood, the shark, the explosions were all fake but felt so real which made the movie more intriguing. Jaws is a sense thrilling blockbuster that will excite your ears eyes and mind.

But Spielberg and John williams were not the only players that brought this movie to stardom. The actors were well chosen and executed the movie almost perfectly. Most of the actors that were chosen for the parts were not even the first pick. Actually Jaws came to be from mostly second choices and improvisations. The introduction for quint was supposed to be in a movie theatre while he watches moby dick, but they couldn't get the rights, and that's how the famous scene of fingernails on the chalkboard and the famous quote "Y'all know me. Know how I earn a livin'. I'll catch this bird for you, but it ain't gonna be easy. Bad fish. Not like going down the pond chasin' bluegills and tommycods. This shark, swallow you whole. Little shakin', little tenderizin', an' down you go. And we gotta do it quick, that'll bring back your tourists, put all your businesses on a payin' basis. But it's not gonna be pleasant." We will see this reference in the simpsons and many other shows. Also Quint's monologue in the ship about the SS Indianapolis was off script and it was touching and amazing and the reactions of Roy and Richard in the first take are the only natural reactions and had to be used. The most amazing aspect of Jaws is that most of the movie was made with 2nd choices and I could only imagine what it would be like if it was made with everything Spielberg wanted.

The 1975 American thriller Jaws directed by Steven Spielberg and based on Peters Benchley's 1974 novel is a movie to never forget watching. The movie leaves an impact, maybe even being able to leave fear or paranoia of going down the beach to some people. Spielberg does an amazing job of portraying suspense. He does this by playing that infamous music in the background or taking slow, peaceful shots of the scenery before a head floats out of a boat. The main characters and their desire to catch the shark make them hero like which is why they are characters to give props to.
An example of the peaceful shots in the movie to create suspense includes one of the very first shots of the girl running into the water and floating. The audience has an idea that something is going to happen but the scenery is calm and the shot of her floating is slow which makes everyone nervous for her. Foreshadowing plays a big part in this movie as well especially the part where Chief Brody doesn't want his son to take the boat in the ocean so he tells him to put it in the bay side. What Spielberg wants you to think that everything is going to be okay because the boat is in the calm bay. There are pauses in dialogue between the chief and his son which makes suspicion rise within the audience. Another shot that catches the audience by surprise is when Hooper dives down to track the shark but the audience is introduced to a scene that makes them jump out of their seat. Overall, between the scary music and peaceful shots in the movie the audience is definitely thrilled. 
Roy Scheider plays the town chief police, Brody, and is someone to connect to because he wants the best for everyone. He was originally scared of going out in the water and what makes him even more likeable is that he ends up going out for the sake of his town. There is no doubt in my mind that if Quint, "Robert Shaw", wasn't in this movie then it wouldn't of have been as good as it was. Shaw brought an edge to the movie because at first you almost hate him for being such an ass but he ends up bringing life to the movie because how funny he is. He doesn't mean to be funny but because he doesn't care what other people think it makes the audience envy him in a way. Shaw plays a fisherman who is obsessed with hunting the shark and his dedication is obvious. It's great how he wants to out show Richard Dreyfuss who plays Hooper, a ichthyologists. As soon as they meet each other Hooper feels disrespected, it's like watching brothers fight but Quint will always win. The characters have conflicts and may not understand each other but they are all certain how much they want this shark to be destroyed.

Jaws - The number one horror movie known to keep people away from the beach, and also a timeless classic. I tell ya, I have never been the type to be scared during, nor after films - I get startled easily by jumpscares, but for the most part, it's just easily brushed off. Not this film. It was intense throughout the whole ride, from start to finish, and it don't hurt that the effects at the time still hold up beautifully, thanks to Spielberg's amazing talent in film work and dedication. I will say that the story itself was predictable - but that's a given when you have a lot of later films copying off of this one to ride on its coattails. Like, you could tell that someone was going to die in that scene where the people are swimming in the water on Fourth of July, but at the same time, it seemed like it was intended to be that way to build up suspense, and that it did. It goes to show that predictability can sometimes make something pretty unpredictable. 
	Not only that, but the characters in Jaws were both very memorable and relatable, something that is unheard of in a lot of horror movies. In most horror films, you got these either morally ambiguous or grade A jerks that end up being eaten, and then you have the protagonist who acts as the audience surrogate. Here, our main guy is Chief Martin Brody, and while he is the chief of police in Amity Island, you also see that he has a family that he wants to protect from the man eating shark lurking in the ocean. In one scene, you see the three main heroes hunting down Jaws, Quint, Brody, and Hooper, all of them talking together over a drink telling horror stories about their adventures by the ocean. Not only does it help with relating with the audience, but it makes the possible death of any of them all the more intense and that kind of storytelling is what makes Jaws so memorable. It's a story and characters first, effects and scares second - they don't have to rely on cheap gore or shock to make people invested and enjoy the film. People come back for the adventure of it all, and the impact that it has on them in how it combines its horror elements with its great writing and development is enough on its own to be a classic on any movie shelf.
