Peter Benchley and Steven Spielberg conspired to make me terrified to even take a bath when they created this classic movie. Straight away, we have to deal with the giant rubber shark that leaps onto the boat towards the climax of the movie. It didn't really work in the 1970s and it really doesn't work now but by the time it appears, it ceases to matter as the sheer terror has been well established. The movie is formed of two distinct acts. Firstly, we have the onshore story of how the small American community of Amity Island learn of the monstrous, great white shark that has come to visit their shallows at the start of the holiday season. While in the second act, we go aboard the fishing vessel Orca with her captain, the local police chief and a shark expert and follow their attempt to track and kill the beast. This second act is a real jewel of a character piece thanks to the fine acting talents of Robert Shaw, Roy Scheider and Richard Dreyfuss. I love the scene where Shaw's Quint and Dreyfuss' Hooper compare scars in an attempt at one-upmanship and the line from Schneider's Chief Brody "You're going to need a bigger boat!" has entered film legend. There's also that terrific score by John Williams that does so much to terrify the viewer. The theme is now such a part of popular culture that there can be few of us that haven't had those menacing bars of music reverberating through our heads at some point while we paddle in the sea at Paignton.
A cerebral horror, a nail biting suspense, and a magnificent adventure epic, Jaws is a masterpiece classic that is thoroughly engaging and has all the elements of a terrific story.

'Jaws' is a classic example of a masterpiece in cinematic movie making. I watched it on the remastered Blu-ray edition today for the first time since I last watched it probably 15 years ago either on VHS or DVD. It's a film I've so rarely seen that I'd almost forgot the main and finer details and indeed the plot developments which happen over the entire course of its 2 hour run time. I'd forgotten who the sharks victim's were and how the film ended. In fact, I almost completely forgotten the last third of the film until today.

For some films, time does not treat them well, and there are certain 'classics' ('Once Upon a Time in America'/'The Deer Hunter' to name two) which are not particularly good. I feared this would this would be the case with Jaws, especially as I could barely remember any of it, indicating that my viewing of it was a forgettable experience. Well, that assumption couldn't have been further from the truth. The direction and cinematography are (still) outstanding, the story is paced nicely provided a few jumps and plenty of tension and suspense along the way. The acting is solid from all the cast, and the main protagonists are all likeable and memorable in their own (often midly quirky) way. Clearly I wasn't paying attention when I watched 'Jaws' all those years ago! I was also surprised to learn just how good the effects and the formidable shark have stood the test of time.

Of further note, the remastered Blu-ray is probably one of the best I've had the pleasure to experience. Spielberg and Co. were on the board for this remaster, and it clearly shows. The picture quality, and all that entails, is superb for a film of this age, but what utterly stunned me was just how well they remixed and remaster the audio. Due to the fact that this film was produced and released (1975) in the 70's, it's hardly surprising that the original track was produced in mono. The Blu-ray remix and remaster is now in 7.1, but this is probably the only remix of a film of this age that works this well, at least on my experience. Most of the remix is largely front heavy (with the exception of the superb musical score) but it provides excellent and natural spacing. But there are also occasional (when the scenes call for it) nicely placed discrete effects that really brings the viewer into the scene. The dialogue is also super clear but not tinny or abrasive like some dialogue recording of a similar era. Quite simply, like the film itself, this is a remaster that defies the test of time and sounds much more modern than it is. 5/5

Jaws has alluded me for years now. As someone who respects and loves the work of Steven Spielberg, I always avoided this one film of his, possibly one of his most important films, due to the simple fact that I don't enjoy horror films and thought this was apart of that genre. After actually viewing the film however, I must concede that I was completely wrong and robbing myself of the enjoyment of this masterful film for much longer than necessary. The film is less about the aspect of horror and sheer destruction and death that the shark can bring, and is much more about the characters and their fears of the unknown. Chief Brody, being scared of the ocean, boats, and anything sea related, Quint who saw his brothers and sisters in uniform while serving in the Navy being ripped apart by sharks, and by Hooper who wants to prove his knowledge of sharks and abilities on this journey, all these characters make for a compelling 2 hour film that masterfully gives you emotion and backstory to characters without drawn out flashbacks or over the top reactions. Most of the backstory if given simply through dialogue between characters which the viewer pieces together, I always appreciate that sort of story telling. The music is famously fantastic thanks to the amazing work of John Williams, the shark himself still holds up as special effects today thanks to the practicality of him, and the entire message of the film still stands the test of time. The message of fearing the unknown but tackling it anyways for the betterment of our lives. Truly an amazing film that I implore anyone who has avoided it for the same reasons as I, to watch it immediately.

I admittedly think Steven Spielberg is a rather overrated director - he seems to make quantity over quality - but boy, this film certainly falls into the quality category, and we need to remember this was one of the director's first few movies.

It amazes me that we got such a great film when there were a lot of problems on set, the most significant one being the mechanical shark not working properly. I believe they also weren't on schedule and definitely went over budget for this film. Spielberg was very clever to compensate for the mechanical shark though - he turned to suspense, a la Hitchcock, to frighten the audience by not actually showing the shark until halfway through the film, which was a brilliant decision. Who knows? Maybe the film would have seemed more quirky if more of the mechanical shark was shown if it wasn't malfunctioning.

The character development of Brody is simple, yet really strong and smart for the context of the movie. When you're up against a giant shark to defend an island community, what a train wreck it is to be afraid of the water. At the conclusion with the closing line "I used to hate the water, I can't imagine why" we know he's come full circle - if Brody can take on a monster of the sea, what makes you think water would still scare him?

Jaws also has some really good humor, a lot of it stemming from the character played by Richard Dreyfuss. The quirky shark-studier is a great character to balance out the tension between a man who wants to protect his community and a man who has a personal vendetta against sharks - who by the way delivers one of the best monologues in film history.

One thing that bothers me is that Brody is blamed for the first couple of victims when the mayor of the town puts heavy pressure on Brody to keep the beaches open in order to turn a profit. It doesn't bother me in the sense that it is a bad aspect of the film, it just seems unfair, and you sort of sympathize with Brody since he wanted to protect the community and he let the community down. If anything, this is a great aspect of the film if it gets you to sympathize with Brody like it did for me.

Even though this film is PG, maybe hold off on showing it to kids (unless they close their eyes at certain points) as it can upset them easily - I was terrified of Quint spurting out blood at the end of the film as a child. In general though, this is a movie everyone should see in their lifetime.

Let me tell you about one of the most important and successful films in cinema history. It was based on a novel by a first-time author. A Hollywood studio optioned the rights to the book even before its publication and then hired a director whose only other feature film had yet to be released and who later tried to back out of the job. The original screenwriter was the novel's author and he quit after producing three adaptations which were all rejected by the studio as inadequate. The novel was a surprise hit, but the director decided to drop or change several of the book's major plot points as well as the personalities of the main characters and the basic tone and focus of the story.  When the director first heard the core music for the film's score, he laughed, thinking it was a joke.

Less than two weeks before production on the movie began, two of the three lead roles were yet to be cast. The script was worked on by several more people who declined screenwriting credit and was ultimately finished by one of the film's actors, who continued working on the script throughout production, often finishing writing scenes the evening before they were to be filmed. The young director stubbornly insisted on filming in a much more problematic setting than other available options. On set, persistent mechanical problems with the movie's key props forced the director to completely change how he wanted to shoot the movie - and caused the movie to go increasingly over budget and behind schedule. In the end, filming took nearly three times the number of allotted days and cost about two and a half times its original budget. Even then, the director insisted on shooting one more sequence that the studio refused to pay for, leading him to use his own money and shoot in a backyard swimming pool.

When it came time to release the film, the studio gave it a wide release and opened it in the summertime, both of which were usually only done when the studio expected a movie to perform poorly at the box office. The movie I've been talking about is "Jaws", which opened on June 20, 1975. I guess you could say that everything turned out alright for this movie and the people who made it. More on that later. First, for those who haven't been fortunate enough to see it, a little about the movie itself.

"Jaws" is the story of a single great white shark and the havoc it wreaks when it camps out in the waters off of the fictional New England resort called Amity Island. When a swimmer's mutilated remains are discovered on the beach, the town's new police chief (Roy Scheider) attempts to close the beaches, but is overruled by the town's mayor, who fears the impact on the town's economically crucial tourist season. After the shark claims some more victims, the beaches are finally closed, right on July 4th weekend. Chief Brody, visiting oceanographer Matt Hooper (Richard Dreyfuss) and a grizzled local fisherman known as Quint (Robert Shaw) set out in Quint's boat, on a mission reminiscent of "Moby Dick". Whether for money (Quint), professional reasons (Hooper) or to protect his family and the rest of the town (Brody), the three men are determined to kill that shark - at any cost.

"Jaws" is a very effective film which is part thriller and part monster movie. Whether originally planned this way or not, the limited number of times we actually see the shark builds the suspense, which is only further enhanced by the film's score. The shedding of some of the book's subplots, allows for better character development, which makes the characters both more interesting and more likeable than they were in the book. The movie's extras are mainly locals from the actual shooting location (Martha's Vineyard, Massachusetts) and many of them have small speaking parts. Unfortunately, the overall quality of the acting suffers a bit from this heavy use of non-actors, but the especially strong performances from Scheider, Dreyfuss, Shaw and several others make up for it. The story's slowly building tension is punctuated by moments of sheer terror and even a few humorous moments, as well as some very memorable scenes and oft-quoted lines ("You're gonna need a bigger boat."), all of which makes "Jaws" one of the best balanced and most engaging horror thrillers in film history.

Now, let me tell you a little bit more about one of the most important and successful films in cinema history. As mentioned earlier, things turned out alright for "Jaws" and the people who made the movie. That two note combination (E and F) that made Spielberg laugh when he first heard it played on the piano signaled the shark's presence throughout the movie and became one of the most recognizable pieces of music in the history of cinema. The composer, John Williams, went on to win an Oscar for his score and later said that "Jaws" jump-started his career. Speaking of which, Spielberg went on to become one of America's best-loved and most successful directors, earning seven Best Director Oscar nominations and eight Best Picture nominations as co-producer, winning Oscars for "Schindler's List" (Best Director and Best Picture) and "Saving Private Ryan" (Best Director). (Word is that he's also gotten better at shooting on schedule and within budget.)

"Jaws" itself became the highest-grossing film in history, up to that time (holding the record for two years, until the release of "Star Wars"), and spawned three sequels and many forms of merchandising. Today, "Jaws" is considered the father of the summer blockbuster. The movie's marketing and release strategy has become the industry standard for big summer releases. Having said all that, regardless of the struggles overcome to bring this movie to theaters or the wide-ranging impact that it had on moviemaking overall, the most important thing about "Jaws" is that it's a damn fine movie that still holds up well today.

I have to say I'm a tiny bit annoyed right now that Jaws isn't listed under the horror category. Horror is a very under-appreciated genre and it deserves this movie. With that said, Jaws is my favorite horror movie. Just about every scene in this masterpiece can be taken apart and analyzed. You want to know how to scare an audience? Take a look at the scene where Brody is throwing chum in the water and Jaws pops up. So many points can be raised about that scene to illustrate how to do a jump scare right. And there's enough praise to go around for every actor involved. From the concerned and feeling powerless expression on Brody's face, to the youthful energy of Dreyfuss, and Robert Shaw was born to play Quint. I like every movie Shaw has done, but this is his most noteworthy role. He plays it so well the first time I watched the movie I thought maybe they found a real fisherman who lived in Amity and they really paid him to hunt their shark. Speaking of the shark, it looks very authentic. Roger Ebert once said Speilberg told him the secret to bring a puppet to life is by putting emphasis on the eyes, and he's right. Too many monster movies hide the eyes of their monster because the eyes are the hardest part to make look realistic, but they're the most important part, which Spielberg has proven with E.T. and Jaws. Besides the great acting and special effects, the music is very important, too, maybe even more so than everything else. My opinion is with horror, and with all genres to some extent, the music is the key factor and many movies fail because of neglect in the music department. Look at all the popular horror movies: Jaws, Halloween, Friday The 13th, The Exorcist, and so on. They all have soundtracks that are awesome, creepy and get stuck in your head. Now look at good horror movies that aren't so popular, like Child's Play and Hellraiser. I would argue that Child's Play is a better horror movie than Friday The 13th, but it has no memorable music so the movie is forgettable. Look at how virtually all modern horror movies have lazy music and are forgettable. Well, it's hard to make a good soundtrack when it's interrupted constantly by jump scares. Anyway, enough about my movie theories. Jaws is the Citizen Kane of horror movies and everyone should see it at least once.

There is a famous saying; imitation is the highest form of flattery. Yet often said imitation can be to the original's detriment, as it undermines its power. But like all classics, it doesn't matter how many tryhard attempts at recreating a masterpiece appear on our cinema screens, there is no denying the pure injection of fear which comes from watching Steven Spielberg's masterpiece; Jaws.

The story takes place in a sunbaked little town called Amity Island, a town which lives for the summer because the tourists come to town. But things are thrown into disarray when new-to-town Police Chief Martin Brody (Roy Scheider) discovers the victim of a shark attack on one of the beaches. Unwilling to lose the influx of customers as a result of the tourist season, Mayor Vaughn decides to keep the beaches open. After the attacks continue, however, Chief Police Brody, icthyologist (read: shark nerd) Matt Hooper (Richard Dreyfuss) and local shark hunter Quint (Robert Shaw), unite to hunt the shark down.

Steven Spielberg is the man to be thanking for this masterpiece. Without him, the film could have turned into an uninteresting shark fest which would work for shock value but wouldn't have the devastating impact that it still has today. What could have been a string of disjointed set-pieces is put together brilliantly to make this film one of the greatest horrors of all time. The mystery and restraint shown by Spielberg throughout the film is reason enough to call him a genius, not to mention the expert characterisation which he cleverly weaves in here and there. Each of our characters are fleshed out and 3-dimensional, as well as being equal parts loveable and frustrating. The perfect use of music, the incredible camerawork, the nerve shredding moments of fear, all of it is put together seamlessly by a master at work. There are moments of pure shock and there are moments of extended tension which will have you tearing at the cushion which you hold for comfort. One thing's for certain, it keeps you on your toes.

The acting in this film is far over and above what you'd get in today's cookie-cutter horrors. Roy Scheider is great as Police Chief Martin Brody. He shows the incredible frustration which his character feels as he is overruled again and again by a man motivated by greed. He shows that he can do humour as well, with wry lines like "He's in the yard not too far from the car." But while he is great as our lead, It's Richard Dreyfuss who steals the show as the more-than-slightly hyperactive Matt Hooper. Like an over-caffinated obsessive-compulsive, Dreyfuss inhabits his character perfectly, showing his indignation, his frustration and his fear with a childlike exuberance which makes him such a likeable character. Robert Shaw plays the almost crazy shark hunter Quint and is fantastic in his role. He mumbles, working class hero-like through his lines "You go in the cage, cage goes in the water, you go in the water? Shark's in the water. Our shark." with a perfect condescending feel which suits his character to a tee. The comradery between these three characters is one of the best parts of the film, and as three initially different characters begin to accept and even embrace one another for their differences, you can almost forget that there is a monster shark on the loose. This is a tribute to not only Spielberg for luring us into a false sense of security, but the realistic relaxation by the actors onscreen which double the effect.

Every part of this brilliant film works together perfectly in order to create this incredible experience. Yes, accidents on set did make scary scenes even scarier and the experience made Spielberg vow to never film on open sea again, but there's not too many films which can boast that an audience ran out of the cinema, into the bathroom, threw up, and ran back inside to keep watching the test screening. It's a morbidly fascinating and pants-wettingly scary film which have you steering clear of beaches for some time, yet coming back for repeat viewings over and over again.

Ah, the big one. It really is impossible to overstate the significance Jaws had on build-up horror, and that lingering fear before you jump in a kiddie pool. Loosely based on a series of shark attacks off the Jersey Shore in 1916, Jaws is the [shark]tail of a picturesque New England island plagued by a series of brutal shark attacks, and the relentless pursuit of said shark by the police chief, a marine biologist and a rouge fisherman. Spielberg overcame numerous setbacks and achieved legendary status with a "less-is-more formula" so hard to emulate now it's near mythical. Building up the suspense and turning the screws unbearably tightly in the first half, Jaws then comes full circle and nudges into all-out horror for its second half. The fact that it is also a finely-nuanced, character-driven drama is due to Bruce's constant malfunctions, forcing Spielberg to improvise a little subtlety. We all know how it turned out in the end...

Spielberg's deft direction, Benchley and Gottlieb's thrilling script, three compelling lead performances - Jaws will always be one of those special films that I never take for granted, simply 'cause it almost never came to be. After all that happened during production, Universal had every right to just pull the plug on the project. Great risk led to great reward, though, as this is now regarded as one of the greatest and most influential films of all-time. This was Spielberg's trial by fire, and he succeeded. Today, we look back on his career - Close Encounters of the Third Kind, the Indiana Jones films, E.T., The Color Purple, Schindler's List, Minority Report, Lincoln - and it's rare to find a filmmaker who's carved out such consistent quality for so long. Greatness had to start somewhere, though, and it began with Jaws.

That's right, until July 2014 I had never seen Jaws. I approached it with some trepidation because, even without seeing the movie, pop culture has made me aware of the general plotline. Not to mention the fact that I had seen several scenes from the film (including the final climactic moment.) So, being fully aware of so much before watching, I was afraid that it would not be able to impact me in any way. I could not have been more wrong! Spielberg deserves every accolade he has received for this movie because every piece of the puzzle that goes into constructing the scenes was perfectly thought out in order to create amazing tension. For instance in that final climax, even though I had literally seen this part of the film before, I was on the edge of my seat and holding my breath. A big part of that is the script. It is built just right, with enough moments between the action that allow us to catch our breath and become invested in the characters. Even Quint, easily the least likable of the main characters has a moment where you see some of what made him the man he is today, and you can't help rooting for him because of this. 

The trio of lead actors are a perfect mix of personalities and I like the performances we get from Roy Scheider, Richard Dreyfuss, and Robert Shaw. It is vital in a film of this kind that we become connected with the protagonists so we can feel like a part of their struggle to beat this shark, and the high-quality acting helps a lot. But the most impressive aspect of Jaws is the stress Spielberg creates in the audience. After only seeing one death scene in the opening, somehow they filled me with uneasiness every moment someone is in or even near the water. And, even though I tried, I can't pinpoint one aspect that made me feel this way. Was it the score? The lighting? The reaction shots from the actors? I just don't know, but even in scenes where there was clearly no danger I was still worried that any time a shark could pop up and the ocean would fill with red. I understand that after this movie came out there were people who literally became nervous about swimming in pools or even taking a bath, and I totally understand that. This kind of strong excitement and anticipation is something I rarely experience when I watch movies, it takes something truly special. I have a feeling that, with a few more viewings, Jaws could become one of my favorite films of all time and I could boost this rating to a perfect 5 stars. I wish I could see it on a big screen. "Must see" is not a strong enough recommendation for this movie!

Still swimming mightily in the hippest of H'Wood waters, film's first bona fide summer popcorn blockbuster possesses as thrilling and entertaining a bite as it did nearly 40 years ago. And yes, the rubber mechanical shark still looks a bit dodgy. It looked dodgy back then as well, however, which is why the captain of this ship hid it away until nearly the end of the film...well, that and the fact that it luckily kept breaking, that is. Granted, Jaws didn't invent the genre. In fact, the film employs a Hitchcockian style of suspense in building up to a slowburn reveal of the actual shark. And, at its heart, the film remains a first-rate monster movie that often baits its audience from the creature's underwater point of view in the tradition of Universal horror classic The Creature from the Black Lagoon. Indeed, a certain soon-to-be legendary director knew his film history which is a major reason why he became a part of film history. Because of his vision, all aspects - from letter perfect performances to expertly written script to powerful score to masterful direction - amount to a ridiculously exhilarating scaremaker of the highest order--then, now, and for years to come.

In this surprisingly PG-rated thriller, a police chief (Roy Sheider), marine biologist (Richard Dreyfuss), and seasoned fisherman (Robert Shaw) set out to stop a gigantic great white that's threatening the island town of Amity during its busiest tourist season.

Regardless of the legendary technical problems that plagued the process, the production also boasted a weapons grade talent who still would've been on a superstar trajectory whether the mechanical shark worked or not. Indeed, the path to Close Encounters of the Third Kind, E.T., The Color Purple, Jurassic Park, Schindler's List, Saving Private Ryan, and Lincoln may've been different without Jaws, but this director was always bound for greatness. Spielberg cut his teeth on television (Rod Serling's Night Gallery, Marcus Welby, M.D.) and already had a few flicks under his belt (Duel, Sugarland Express), but consider that his landmark filmmaking touchstones were already in full effect in Jaws. Framing ordinary people in extraordinary situations. Maintaining humanity and morals while facing inhuman terror. Finding humor even in the most horrific of moments. Zoom-in close ups of his star's awe-struck faces. It's all there, along with soon-to-be frequent collaborators John Williams (giving us an unforgettable - admit it, it's playing in your head right now - score) and Richard Dreyfuss (giving us a quirky career-making performance). Roy Scheider, who Spielberg admired in another '70s classic called The French Connection, brings an authentic feel to the lead character, Police Chief Brody, which grounds the drama all the more. Luckily, the script developed the players beyond caricatures. Perhaps, no character evinces this more than Robert Shaw's Quint, who turns from a salty son of a sea cook into a tortured survivor with one speech that gets burned into your mind forever from the first time you hear it. When talk came of Jaws 2, Spielberg initially wanted nothing to do with the inevitable sequel. At one point during pre-production of the film, however, he reportedly entertained one possibility. What if they made it a prequel based solely on Quint's searing USS Indianapolis speech, a chilling first-hand account of hundreds of sailors getting picked off by sharks in icy waters following their vessel getting torpedoed that was written by writer/director John Milius (Conan the Barbarian, Red Dawn)? The sharks at Universal, of course, said 'no.' Perhaps, this muted prequel idea remains one of H'Wood's greatest unfulfilled coulda-beens. Without this follow-up, we'll just have to make do with the scary near perfection of Jaws. Lucky us.

Bottom line: Here's to STILL swimming with bow-legged women

Director Steven Spielberg put himself on the map with his famed father of summer blockbusters on June 20, 1975.  The highest-grossing film in history at the time of its release, Jaws established a formula for future summer pictures to follow, which places greater focus on high concept premises and action-adventure.
   Its story is based on the novel of the same by Peter Benchley.  A great white shark begins to terrorize swimmers at a small New England resort town, and the police chief, Brody (Roy Scheider, The French Connection), responds by closing the beaches. But, as the profitable Fourth of July is fast approaching, Mayor Larry Vaughn (Murray Hamilton) reopens them, allowing the shark to continue wreaking havoc upon the shoreline. When the shark attacks Brody's son, Brody, oceanographer Matt Hooper (Richard Dreyfus, American Graffiti), and shark hunter Quint (Robert Shaw, From Russia with Love) set out to sea to destroy the beast.
    Jaws's three leads are sharply written and possess strong personalities that sometimes band them together and sometimes drive them apart. The interactions between them and other characters are precise, unique and nuanced; they all feel real.  However, while the scholarly Hooper and crusty Quint have acquired sea legs and have exciting professions, Scheider's Brody is the everyman caught in the middle of an extraordinary conflict, an archetype that Spielberg now commonly employs.  He is a man who knows what is right, but finds himself chained by society's foolishness and, as a result, more deaths follow.  Thus, Brody's motivations for destroying the shark are both personal and moral - he intends to right his past wrongs and protect his family and town. Plus, he's scared of water, and that's definitely not helpful in a movie that spends a lot of time in the open ocean.
   The action is endlessly thrilling.  As the mechanical shark suffered from a multitude of technical problems, it remains hidden for most of the movie, and that makes Jaws incredibly powerful.  Because the human mind has the tendency to fear the unknown, the shark becomes more than just a monster; it becomes a dark, ominous presence implied by John Williams's superb score and attacks seen from its point of view, causing us to construct a horror beyond comprehension within our own minds.  In a stroke of genius, the camera focuses only on the panicked thrashing of the first victim (Susan Backlinie) and her piercing screams, her desperate pleads to God - the death is brutal because we see and feel her fear. Gore is sparsely used, but when it does appear, it is all the more shocking.  Spielberg makes us wait until we see the shark for the first time, building suspense and excitement all the way to the climactic battle. And yes, while the shark has a habit of looking like the robot it is whenever its head fully emerges from the water, one can't deny that it is an impressive feat of engineering that mostly fulfills its purpose during its brief screen time during the film's final act.
   Spielberg's shark flick is also a lot deeper than people credit it to be. Quint, a character just as greedy as the mayor, seeks to exploit the town's money in return for catching the shark. He is in the quest for glory, selfish desire, and to fulfill a personal vendetta against all sharks, so it's no coincidence that he's the only lead character who perishes.  The shark itself represents the force of nature and shares a relationship to Quint similar to the one between Moby Dick and Captain Ahab.  It attacks people not because it is evil, but because it is just an animal seeking to survive. Humans in the film, and real life, habitually tempt fate, venturing into regions where they have no right to be, regions occupied by other living creatures, regions where interactions between man and beast are inevitable. Instead of understanding this as an inevitability, humans, like Quint, seek to right perceived wrongs by creatures seen as evil only because that concept is assigned to them. With that in mind, the movie is less black and white than it seems. Like the great Shakespearean plays, Jaws holds a mirror up to us and forces us to truly examine ourselves.
   Jaws is an ambitious, adventurous and masterful film that takes a deceptively simple concept and executes it to the highest degree through iconic performances, fantastic spectacle, and excellent mood-building devices. It is one of those rare movies that makes us forget about reality and draws us in completely. Though Spielberg and his daring crew battled numerous setbacks and failures during a long, arduous shoot, the film remains triumphant to this day because its creators came up with creative ways to overcome its problems. Perhaps more so than any of its peers, Jaws is very much the definition of "art through adversity."

About a bloodthirsty shark terrorizing innocent beach-goers, JAWS was the first of its kind to become define the term "blockbuster" hit, grossing over $100 million at the box office in its 1975 year of release.  It also put a then unknown Steven Spielberg on the map as a skillful director.  Humorously, though, JAWS went through a LOT of difficulties during production period, mainly on account of a "mechanical" shark that malfunctioned more often than not.  But you wouldn't know this from watching the end result.  The film is tightly edited (using whatever "usable" footage of said shark could be used), and arguably benefits from a lot of moments where we don't actually see the shark as it stalks its next victim, but follow its point of view.  (This was mainly due to complications with the technology back then.)  But it was John Williams' foreboding, thumping score that really set the tone for this energetic thriller.  Having said all this, what really makes JAWS is the dynamic between Roy Schieder, Richard Dreyfuss, and Robert Shaw as the heroic trio who set out to kill the shark.  All three are fleshed out as compelling, interesting characters that allows the audience to identify with them, making the grand climax all the more satisfactory.  JAWS spawned three (dubious) sequels of degrading quality, but the original remains a classic, and deservedly so.

One of the greatest monster movies of all time and the one that brought director Steven Speilberg to prominence. This film is excellent for three reasons. First, The acting was superb, particularly the interplay between Roy Scheider, Richard Dreyfuss and Robert Shaw. It doesn't hurt that they are played by three highly skilled actors and supported by a script that snaps with great dialog and, for about the last forty minutes, non-stop tension. The most notable example is the long (but not drawnout) scene in the Orca when the three discuss their fears and motivations for catching the shark. 

Second, the deirection by Spielberg.  Spielberg takes a lot of time for character development, but he doesn't lump it all together at the beginning of the filmScenes like Brody's son mocking Brody's expressions at the dinner table, or Quint's speech about why he hunts sharks, are crucial to understanding the motivations of characters, but Spielberg makes sure they come at times where a release of tension is needed.

Finally, the ingenious music that John Williams composed for the film, especially the two note theme that announces the impending arrival shark, which has become part of our pop culture. Other production aspects deserve mentions as well, from Bill Butler's superb cinematography to the mechanical shark itself, which, despite the well-known tales of it not working most of the time, still looks menacing.

Jaws is one of the best monster movies ever made simply because it takes time to explore the human side of its story.  It is a penetrating drama, a kind of throwback to 1950's monster films.  It influenced films such as Alien and  Deep Blue Sea, whether in the general construction of story, the setting, or more literal takes on a monster in a closed environment. Even if this weren't the case, Jaws would still be essential viewing for anyone serious about film.

Prior to the summer of '75, I loved to play in the ocean at the Jersey shore. That summer, I built sand castles. Jaws was the very first movie that literally changed my life. The movie is horror and suspense perfection.

A string of fatal shark attacks have beached on Amity Island's doorstep in the week leading up to the 4th of July weekend, the Island's biggest tourist attraction of the year. Local Deputy of Chief Police, Martin Brody (played by Roy Scheider), struggles to get the Mayor to understand that the beaches must be closed to prevent any more deaths. Unfortunately, Mayor Larry Vaughn fears the opposite; closing the beaches will ruin Amity Island's summer tourist season, the town's primary income source for the year.

It's not long into the film before we and the terrified people of Amity Island discover that this creature of the sea is not one to be messed with. Unseen for the majority of the film (mainly the first half) Steven Spielberg creates a fear of the unknown. And who doesn't fear the unknown? Clever use of the camera and iconic musical score hints that danger is nearby but for the poor guy on screen, they have no idea what's lurking underneath them. It captures the feeling of helplessness I have every time I swim in the ocean, or even when I was younger just in the local swimming pool. Maybe it was Jaws that made me feel this in the first place!

Throughout the film, floating objects are used to portray the sharks sense of direction. One scene in particular shows an old wooden dock being snapped out of place and dragged out to sea by the shark before turning and charging back to a panicking swimmer. By using the wooden dock not only can we see the unknown but also register it's sheer strength. It's a monster.

I had to wonder who the 'villain' of this film really is. The man-eating killer shark  doing what it can to get by or the 'putting everyone's life in stake for profit' Mayor. One shocking scene halfway through the film shows a crowded beach with nobody in the water. The Mayor walks over to a friend, a father with his family, and forces them to get in. They do so unwillingly, their faces read pure fear but eventually it leads to a sea filled buffet for the shark (I don't refer to the shark as Jaws because that's just the name of the film, not the shark itself). It may be shocking but it was a shockingly great way to make the Mayor even more of a douche.

Martin Brody soon teams up with shark enthusiast Matt Hooper and shark hunter Quint. There's some tension between them which is escalated with the fact they are alone on a small boat out in the ocean. It creates exciting chemistry when they are risking their lives trying to catch this beast. Despite having more camera time in this part of the movie, the shark looks and moves incredibly well for a film from the 70?s. It definitely still holds up today.

It's been almost 40 years since it's release and still Jaws remains as one of the best suspense/thriller film ever released. If you haven't seen this film for whatever reason you need to check it out. If you've already seen it before, maybe it's time to watch it again.

- One of the first real blockbusters was this 1975 'Jaws' from director Steven Spielberg (Jurassic Park, Schindler's List). Based on the novel by Peter Benchley, this film is one of the most terrifying films of all times. The big star: a man-eating great white shark (in reality a huge mechanic dummy). I really love this film; it's man versus nature, and it music composition by the genius John Williams (everyone knows the tune) is absolutely nerve-racking. The movie was so successful that it got three more sequels and formed an inspiration for many other shark-movies. In the main cast we have Roy Scheider (the French Connection), Robert Shaw (From Russia With Love), Richard Dreyfuss (Close Encounters of the Third Kind) and Lorainne Gary (Jaws franchise). A classic to put your teeth in. 

When Amilty Island's Sheriff Martin Brody (Scheider) finds the remains of a girl who was attacked by a shark when she went skinny-dipping in the night, he wants to close down the beach for swimmers. But that's against the will of the local business people, who make a living by the summer tourists, so the mayor denies Brody's request. Shortly after that, the Sheriff and his wife Ellen (Gary) witness several other attacks. One almost killed their son Michael. With this many casualties, something needs to be done. Brody joins the local shark hunter Quint (Shaw) and Marine biologist Matt Hooper (Dreyfuss) to track the shark down.  The three men set out on the vessel Orca and plan on killing the terrifying sea creature...

In 1975, a relatively unknown director at the time, Steven Spielberg decided to make a movie like no other about a man-eating shark. The project proved to be extremely difficult, with many huge delays to difficulties in operating the mechanical, animatronic shark. There were tons of production delays and due to going way over-budget, Spielberg thought this was the end of his filmmaking career and many thought the film was going to be the biggest disaster in the history of film. When Jaws was released however, audiences were wowed and scared by it, breaking many records, and this film, along with George Lucas's Star Wars, are credited for the founding of the summer blockbuster. It also made Spielberg one of the most successful directors of all-time, creating other acclaimed films like Close Encounters of the Third Kind, Raiders of the Lost Ark, Jurassic Park, and ET.  How does Jaws rank up today compared to modern blockbusters as The Avengers and Lord of the Rings? Well, it's still an amazing, horror thrill ride.

Jaws begins when a great white shark attacks a female skinny dipper at a late-night party. When her remains appear on the beach, Amity police chief Brody (Roy Scheider) intends to close the beaches, but mayor Vaughn (Murray Hamilton), believing that news of the shark attack will hurt the beach business during 4th of July weekend, dismisses it ("When you say shark, then we've got a panic on our hands on the 4th of July."). After several more shark attacks, the Mayor eventually agrees for a major shark hunt. Shark hunters catch a shark, but it's discovered that it's not the shark who attacked. So then, Brody, shark hunter Quint (Robert Shaw), and marine biologist Hooper (Richard Dreyfuss) go on an epic mission to kill the shark before it attacks again.

Also, Lorraine Gray plays Ellen Brody, Brody's wife and Craig Kingsbury plays Ben Gardner, a shark hunter who gets attacked and shows up in a famous jump scene.

Jaws was the film that launched the massive directing career of Steven Spielberg, even though he had made films prior, such as The Sugarland Express. His honors over the years are well deserved, cause it still remains one of his best films. Spielberg has returned to the horror/suspense genre again with films like Jurassic Park and Temple of Doom, but Jaws remains to this day his definitive horror masterpiece.

Originally, the shark was going to be seen more, but due to the mechanical difficulties of the animatronic shark, Spielberg decided to pull an Alfred Hitchcock, where the shark wouldn't be seen at all until towards the end. That concept really makes the film work in it's thrills. I enjoyed the fears and tensions that the shark was going to show up, and it turned out to be a false alarm, and then, the shark shows up finally, which makes Jaws a true horror icon. Now, when we actually see the shark, the mechanicalness of the shark feels a little cheesy and dated in today's times, but the suspense still carries on to where you don't care at all if the shark is a mechanical shark.

For a horror film, there's some fun humor as well, particularly in the scenes on the boat. When the shark shows up for the first time, Brody tells the captain, Quint, "You're gonna need a bigger boat." Another instance. when Brody and Quint are arguing, Hooper mentions, "Oh boys! I think he's back for his noon feeding." I also love the part where Hooper crushes a plastic cup in anger due to frustration over finding the shark. These scenes make us care for the three main characters and their intentions to kill the shark once and for all. 

The casting is also spectacular. Roy Scheider is great as Chief Brody, and I love the fact that he's scared of the water, making his character the more entertaining. Richard Dreyfuss is also well-cast as scientist Brody, and the scene where he goes into a shark cage is one of the most suspenseful sequences in the film, and possibly, film history. The one who really steals the show is Robert Shaw as Quint, the crazy shark hunter. Cleary inspired by Captain Ahab from Moby Dick, Shaw gives it his all and gives us some chilling speeches, particularly a sequence where he tells the audience about his encounter with sharks on the USS Indianapolis, which is based on a real life incident that occurred during WWII. That speech there gives me goosebumps and is just as suspenseful as the shark scenes. 

And speaking of shark scenes, none of the shark scenes would have worked without the score by my all-time favorite composer, John Williams, who became a longtime Spielberg collaborator after the massive success of Jaws. The Jaws theme, which consists of only two notes, is the biggest reason why Jaws works so well in the suspense department. It's dark, creepy, and awesome. There's also some cool, adventure, piratey music that shows up throughout the film that's also a highlight. This is one of Williams's best scores ever, and it definitely deserved the Oscar for Best Score.

Jaws remains a horror landmark, a Spielberg classic, and one of my all-time favorite films. I'm not a big fan of the horror genre, as the overuse on gore has caused the genre to go massively downhill, but Jaws, like Psycho, maintains the level of suspense and scares that creates what an essential horror film should be. No wonder why many people were scared of going back into the water. (I'm not one of these, however.)

Sometimes things do not go as plans and turn out better than you ever could have hoped. Stephen Spielberg wanted to make a movie about a killer shark but it turned out to be one of the scariest movies of its generation. I'm talking, of course, about Jaws. This thriller has a very simple premise but turned out to be one of the best movies ever made. Filmed on Martha's Vineyard, this film was a pain to shoot, but the reward was well worth it.
Jaws had a really strong cast with Robert Shaw, Roy Scheider, and Richard Dreyfuss. Chief Brody struggles to convince his summer town that there is a killer shark in their waters. The big problem is that it is 4th of July weekend and they need this weekend because tourists bring in all the money the town needs to survive. If word gets out of a killer shark that means no money which means no survival. Murray Hamilton plays the foolish mayor who won't listen to reason. The shark kills a few people and push comes to shove. Brody brings in Matt Hooper, a shark expert, and they figure out the shark is a great white. This thing is a cold blooded eating machine. "All this fish does is eat, sleep, and make baby sharks, it's that simple." Eventually, the town hires Quint, a local fisherman and Brody, Quint, and Hooper venture out to kill the shark. That is our story and it really is done so well.
Jaws is based off a book and they are similar. The basic story is obviously the same, character relationships and development is very similar. The only difference is that Hooper and Brody's wife have an affair. In the movie itself we see them get along and build a relationship and its interesting how Spielberg threw a little tease n there for fans of the book. Also the endings were both different which I also find interesting. The movie ending was way more explosive and enjoyable.
As I said this movie was terrifying when it was released in the 70s, but it was scary by accident. The mechanical shark they used was named Bruce, but the thing never worked. To make up for it they only showed parts of the shark. It takes a long time to see what the full shark looks like. Sometimes it's not what you see that is scary, it's what you don't see, and that is what worked so well. We see a girl screaming for her life and getting dragged around, but we don't see what is doing it. It is almost disturbing but it worked and films have copied this tactic time and time again. There were also a lot of problems filming on the open sea. I mention this because any real fan of film would appreciate to know how hard it was to make this movie and how dedicated the filmmakers were to deliver.
Along with the scary images of a torn leg, a decaying face, and blood being spit out of a mouth while the jaws of the shark pierce into the abdomen are horrifying, John Williams makes it ten times worse with two notes. Everybody knows the Jaws theme and how it starts out slow and picks up. As it gets faster and faster the shark gets closer and closer, and finally strikes. Music makes the movie, I say it all the time, and John Williams proves it once again, and he did it with two notes.
Towards the end of the movie all the focus is on Quint, Hooper, Brody, and the shark. Hooper and Quint's relationship is really hysterical. It is old school verses new school. Quint is the rugged fisherman who just makes it up as he goes along. Hooper is the rich college boy with a plan. They butt heads a lot and their sarcastic remarks back and forth are very entertaining.
My favorite scene in the entire movie is towards the end when the three men are on the boat telling stories of how they got their scars from sharks or whatever. Then Quint tells a true story of the USS Indianapolis. The USS Indianapolis was a cruiser that sank and all the sailors were in the water and over a few days sharks attacked and killed mostly everyone. Quint was on that ship and he tells the story. Robert Shaw gives one of the best speeches I have ever seen in any movie. The way he tells the story. "And the thing about a shark is he's got lifeless eyes. Black eyes. Like a doll's eyes." He describes sharks really well and that story was not something I expected form the movie. The true story takes the audience out of the movie and you feel sadness. We dig into Quint's character and even the way the camera just focuses on Quint and how he tells the story. This is a scene I watch twice every time because I love the way he delivers the speech. The only problem I have with the movie itself is that there are two scenes that scare the daylights out of me and I still can't what, and it is impossible to understand what Quint is saying without subtitles.
Overall, Jaws is a classic and I love the way it was made, the people in it, and the movie itself. The movie works and it is nearly flawless. Jaws is a movie everybody alive in this world needs to see at least once. I bought this on blu ray and it was the best up converted movie I have seen so far. The picture was perfect and the sound was amazing. Sometimes I find myself constantly changing the volume of my surround sound but not with Jaws. Jaws easily gets the WillyT Seal of Approval.

I don't imagine there can be such a thing as a "perfect film," but for me, "Jaws" is about as close as you can get. It was one of the most troubled productions in film history, but there was something serendipitous in how all of the elements came together. Everything just works: The story structure, the dialogue, the characters, the cast, the pacing, the cinematography, the editing, the sound design, the music. It's the ultimate man vs. nature story, fusing together equal parts adventure, suspense, comedy, and character drama. The actual, tangible shark animatronic creates a physical connection and sense of tension and dread that has yet to be topped by CGI. The chemistry between the three primary actors is sublime. The scary moments still work every time. The final showdown is glorious. I love every second of this movie.

This is my favorite movie of all time. I have seen it at least 25 times in my life. It is the only movie that I can watch over and over and over again without getting bored of it to some extent. Stephen Spielberg is the man, and he is the greatest film director of all time. What makes him the greatest is how epic his films are. People to this day are still scared to go into the water, because of this film, and I will admit that I do start to think of sharks when I swim a certain distance from shore. I have been watching this since I was ten, and it has been my favorite movie since I was ten.

The film is very different from the book, but I think overall the two are just as good. In the book I thought that the stuff with the town was a lot more interesting, because they gave more detail about their lives, and describe all of the effects closing the beach would have on the town. However I thought that the part in the book with Brody's wife was annoying, and I disliked her and Hooper in the book. I am glad they cut that part out of the movie so the film would be more focused on the shark, and the main characters trying to deal with it. In the book Hooper is more interested in studying the shark, and he doesn't appreciate the danger of it at all. He is an ignorant guy who you really dislike in the book, but they made him much more likeable in the film and I was glad to see that he survived at the end of the film. In the book Quint is exactly the same as he is in the movie, so Robert Shaw gets major props for his performance. The movie has elements that are better then the book, and the book has elements that are better then the movie.

The book has a lot more drama in it. The movie to me was much more suspenseful then the book. The book had a lot more personal drama, and would go a while without hearing about the shark. The book had the drama with Brody's wife, the mayor, and all of the things going through Brody's head. The movie was more suspenseful, because they don't show the shark, or tell you what kind of shark it is until about an hour into the movie. They also do things like making you wonder what is going to happen, and when. The book did have a lot of suspense, but the movie was slower so it could build suspense. Overall they are both equal.

I liked the fact that the shark's movements look mechanical. The reason why is because they really tried to make the shark seem like it was just some kind of machine, and the fact that it looks mechanical when it moves makes it look like a machine too. The shark in Jaws is practically a different breed of Great White sharks. They really do a good job making it seem that way. However there are times when it looks fake, because of the way it's body looks. Because of the technology back then, they couldn't give the shark the body flex that most Great Whites have. When it turns it head left and right it looks like it is being moved by somebody else, because it is mechanical. Also if you pay close enough attention at first it had a light blue on the top half of it's body, but on the 2nd day out there it looked more like it was more black. But other then the few times when it looks like it is clearly a mechanical shark, the use of the mechanical shark. 

An interesting fact is that they named the mechanical shark Bruce on set. Also at first they were supposed to show Bruce in every scene of the movie just like in the book. But nobody had ever used a mechanical shark before, and they were trying to get Bruce to work. Bu they couldn't get Bruce to work in time to start filming so they had to come up with a way to make the movie work without showing the shark until they got it to work. It worked out for the best, and the film is so great because they waited to show the shark. I think that is an example of everything happens for a reason.

Everybody knows the famous line "Your gonna' need a bigger boat." That is an awesome scene because you had been waitng for Jaws to make an appearance, and you can tell they had been out there all day, and then suddenly bam Jaws is there. It is a really well acted scene too. When they watch the shark swim past the boat, and you see how long it is. So amazing. The best scene is when Quint tells the story of when he was on the U.S. Indianapolis. It is such a cool scene, and Robert Shaw's acting was so good in that scene. If you look closely when Brody is out on the bow he grabs a gun, and you see a shooting star go by in the sky. I am sure they did that on purpose to show, that he wishes the shark was dead already.

This film has a lot of surprising things that happen that make you jump when you see them, because they are unexpected. You jump at the scene when Hooper finds the tooth in the boat. I won't spoil the thing that makes you jump for people who haven't seen this yet, but it freaked me out when I first saw it. There are several times when they show the shark and it makes you jump. Though this is not a scary film, it does make you jump at random times. Some people may find this scary, but I didn't.

The scene when they first show the shark is one of my all time favorite movie scenes. First the kids swim in the water with a cardboard fin as a practical joke, but when they finally get busted, a girl on the other side of the island see's the real thing. It goes into the pond where Brody's son is, and eats another man. First you just see the sharks fin, but after it knocks the mans boat upside down, you see it's head moving towards the man with it's mouth open, and he gets pulled under water. It's awesome because of how cool the way they show the sharks head for the first time. If you have seen the movie, you will know what I am talking about. That is the thing Spielberg is the master of different camera angles. He uses the angles to show things in such an interesting way that you always can tell it's his work when you see it. He and Alfred Hitchcock are the masters at camera work.

Not only is this a great man vs. nature story, but also it is a story of conflict, and hard decision making. It is about a man fighting against people to do what is right. Martin Brody knows he must close the beaches, but he is fighting against the mayor to do so. Mayor Vaughn whom you hate, believes only what he wants to believe. He refuses to close the beaches, because that will destroy their summer. Amity Island is a town that makes all of their money during the summer. It would kill the town to close down the beaches. You hate him, because you know people are going to get killed because of him, but at the same time you feel for him, because he is in the worst possible position he could be in. Brody will not get blamed because he wanted to close the beaches so it wouldn't be his fault. That is the big conflict that he faces. The mayor is the antagonist in a certain way. At the end when the mayor learns he was wrong you feel bad for him, because you know how bad he must feel. That is why it has a lot of conflict, and it is about making the hardest decisions. That is why it is so good, because no matter what the mayor does he will get heavily criticized for it.

Another thing about this film is how Spielberg ties his signature style in to it. Like when the shark dies at the end, you see it sinking, and then you hear the dinosaur growl, while there is very peaceful classical music in the background. He gives of all of these emotions that no other director has ever given me, by doing things like that. My favorite scene may be the scene when Brody is sitting at the table, and his son keeps copying all of his motions. It's such a cute scene, and it is so heart warming that scene. The heart warmth I get from Spielberg films is different as I said earlier from other films, and that is a great example of it. The final scene too, when he learns that Hooper is still alive. It was the same feeling, but different. It was a more calming, and southing feeling that you got after all of the action stopped.

This is an easy five stars. A classic and the best shark movie ever made. The script is great, the casting is great, the acting is great, and the direction is great. However, there are some glitches one begins to notice after multiple viewing. Certain scenes are cut in ways that do not make sense and there are lapses in logic in the script itself. But ultimately none of it matters because this is just too much fun to complain about details. 
All the death scenes are well made. All are different and bring something new. The film is edited very well and it builds tension with apparent ease. There is never a dull moment in this film. Even expository scenes are interesting, due to interesting characters and good acting. 
The third act is rather long, but not one minute too long. The pacing is great and you can't cut anything out without disturbing the mood and the flow of events. Every scene counts in this film.

Summer, the most profitable time for multiplex theatres and CGI-explosions factories, has  become synonymous with (arguably) soulless outings of artless money-making. With remakes, reboots, sequels, prequels, franchises, and cinematic universes taking over our local cinemas each mid-year, it's easy to forget that this whole business started with the troubled production of Jaws. Spielberg's coming-out party stands-out 40 years later as a timeless piece of pure capital-F Filmmaking that surpasses most, if not all, that it influenced. With spectacular characters and thrilling scares, it still makes audiences pause before getting in the water.
The modern-day leviathan tale of a tourist town dependent on out-of-towners for their economy (sound familiar, Panama City?) terrorized by a giant shark on July 4th is celebrating its 40th year of keeping audiences dry. The zeitgeist moments are wonderful (jumping mechanical sharks, "you're gonna need a bigger boat"), but those thrills are matched by the timelessly human characters and dialogue. Spielberg grounds the excitement in enough reality to keep us engaged, specifically in the three men at the center. Scheider, Dreyfuss, and Shaw have incomparable chemistry, playing some of the most endearing individuals in movie history.
Sure, the mechanics of the shark itself are somewhat antiquated but that's to be expected. I can only imagine what we will think of the effects in Jurassic World in 2055. The immutability of the personality in Jaws is what has kept us returning to it decade after decade. This Independence Day, celebrate your national freedom by enjoying one of the greatest popcorn films of all time...just make sure you go to the beach first.

Wow! Talk about captivating, Spielberg was at the top of his game here with this movie that cost $9 million dollars and made over $470 million dollars. It was also responsible for introducing the idea of summer block buster releases as the movie was shown in over 450 screens, accompanied by an extensive marketing campaign.

The movie is based on a novel of the same name by Peter Benchley, but Spielberg focused on the main theme "the shark" removing all the other subplots.
Shot mostly on location on Martha's Vineyard, Massachusetts, the film had a troubled production, mostly due to the mechanical shark's malfunctions, it also overran its budget and ran past its schedule, and some of these reasons are why some believe Spielberg opted out of being involved in Jaws 2.

The movie plot was thus: During the summer break some teens were having a night party on fictional Atlantic resort Amity Island.
One of the girls went skinny dipping while her friends continue to party on the beach. 

While waiting for a boy to come join her she got pulled under by something that leaves only you the view with the idea that death came.

When pieces of her body washed ashore, the Police Chief Brody (Roy Scheider) feared that it was a shark attack and wanted to close the beach for the town's safety, but Mayor Vaughn (Murray Hamilton) disagreed.

His point being, the town's people survived mainly on tourist trade and the July 4th holiday was also approaching so he refused to close the beach.

He soon changed his mind after a boy and a man also died due to shark attack. 

He then decided to hire Quint (Robert Shaw), the only local fisherman willing to take on a Great White.

The movie score is something that will stick with you and it resembled that used by classic thriller director Alfred Hitchcock. 

To overcome some of the difficulties encountered Spielberg mostly used an ominous, minimalistic theme created by composer John Williams to indicate the shark's impending appearances.

Jaws have had three sequels, none with the participation of Spielberg or Benchley.

Jaws also won three Academy Awards for Best Film Editing, Best Original Dramatic Score, and Best Sound.  It was also nominated for Best Picture but lost it to One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (which starred Jack Nicolson).

The definitive summer blockbuster and a classic thriller, Jaws broke all ground for director Steven Spielberg, his flawless cast, and Peter Benchley, who penned the novel that inspired the film. It is often imitated by other films that hardly capture the lightning in a bottle that it did. The film is a household name, a favorite among all movie buffs. The terrifying opening hooks us instantly, and as it turns out, the problems behind the scenes turned in the best results. Spielberg's decision to keep the shark under wraps makes the attacks all the more suspenseful. The shark itself looks terrific to this day. There is wonderful character development in Martin Brody (played terrifically by Roy Scheider), his family, and the residents of Amity Island. Richard Dreyfuss's Matt Hooper is a funny and sympathetic character, and Robert Shaw's performance as Quint is pitch-perfect. His U.S.S. Indianapolis speech still gives you the shivers. The final act with the showdown between the three men and the 25-foot, 3-ton Great White still packs a major punch. Overall, the film balances perfect tension with intense shocks, and John Williams' score still scares the hell out of you. After almost 40 years, Jaws never ages. It's a timeless classic that continues to give us good reason to stay out of the water.

The problem of the twenty-first century is the problem of visibility. I am, of course, referring to how movie monsters are always front and center these days. No, I√¢(TM)m not the first person to point that out, or even the hundredth, but after watching the new edition of Jaws on Blu-Ray, I feel like this issue needs to be addressed more than ever. When I watched it, I felt personally threatened by the shark, not just empathetically so. Explain to me how that could happen, and then I could turn to something like Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man√¢(TM)s Chest, and feel nothing when the Kraken shows up and demolishes a massive pirate ship?
	After sitting through the first hour or so of Jaws and finally getting a glimpse of the man-eater, the payoff felt real to me. Steven Spielberg deals little tidbits of the shark to you in the form of either spontaneous violence, or gruesome physical evidence, like the shark tooth that√¢(TM)s the size of a √¢shot glass.√¢? Spielberg, even at the age of 29, was a savvy enough director to understand that our imaginations are far more dangerous than reality usually is. So when we see Brody flipping through a detailed, illustrated book about sharks√¢"and then see all the disastrous stuff from the pictures actually happen√¢"we√¢(TM)re left feeling just as at sea as Brody, Hooper, and Quint (pun definitely intended).
	But the shark√¢(TM)s low profile is not the only reason why Jaws is so great. Even though it was one of the first summer blockbusters, watching it again makes me realize how slow of a burn it is. Of course, the story is paced masterfully; that√¢(TM)s not the problem. Spielberg opens the movie with the moonlit murder of a teenaged girl, and then the next scene is set in Brody√¢(TM)s tranquil seaside house. The contrast is startling, yet organic and effective. Rather than immediately cutting to Brody inspecting the bloody mess left by the shark on the shore, Spielberg lures us into a false sense of security by easing us up to that point. It√¢(TM)s almost more sadistic for Spielberg to treat his audience this way than if he had showed us explicit close-ups of the girl being torn apart underwater.
	Another reason why Jaws is so revered is because of its focus on character. The story does take itself seriously, and never devolves into straight comedy, but the tone of the movie is far from dark. This is because of the levity brought by Hooper, played by Richard Dreyfuss. He√¢(TM)s a younger man than Brody and Quint; he loves sharks and knows a ton about them, but his enthusiasm about his job is boyishly infectious. Compared to Brody and Quint√¢"both of whom have been at their jobs for quite some time now√¢"Hooper is a greenhorn. He is not there for comic relief, because, as a shark expert, he serves a key role in the mission. But without him there for Quint to bicker with, we√¢(TM)d only be left with the two older men to trade somber stories, such as the bummer tale of the U.S.S. Indianapolis. Roy Scheider and Robert Shaw both turn in excellent performances, but I would argue that Dreyfuss is the superior presence here.
	Probably the coolest part about Jaws is that it manages to include all the hallmarks of summer popcorn flicks√¢"boobs, explosions, and violence√¢"without losing its heart. Spielberg has a more professional and nuanced approach than our current crop of blockbuster directors, and so Jaws satisfies both your superego and your id at the same time. It√¢(TM)s a shame that Spielberg, who is still making movies, is not turning out the same quality work as he used to. For me, man vs. shark will always be more interesting than horse vs. war.
